output: Madam Vice-President, the Commission gives the impression of acting like a distracted student who is running after lost time before returning his copy.
Of course, the social package exists, but it is incomplete and can only be considered a step towards the Commission taking into account social issues.

The President of the Commission did not take the measure of the warning given by citizens in France, the Netherlands and Ireland, which would unfortunately have been identical elsewhere in the event of a popular vote.
These elections are reminders of order.
If Europeans want more Europe, it is to build a social project, and not just to adopt even more technical directives.
Regulation concerning the internal market is certainly necessary, but it is not and is far from the essential.
The 2009 program, like the previous ones, will miss the point.
Citizens do not expect the Commission to simply complete or simplify legislation.
They expect the Commission to be up to the task assigned to it by the treaties, the locomotive, the idea box of the Union.
It is not enough for this that its president is wise and silent, keeping an eye on the president of the Council.
We expect the Commission to act as a key player in the reflection on the nature of the society project we need.
But what is the social project in this program?
The 2009 program does not contain serious errors, but it is not the program our fellow citizens need.
Mr. President, it will be up to the new college to take its responsibilities.
I only hope that it will be less deaf to the appeals of the people than the current one.
Mr. President, first of all, a question to the Council.

What about the high-level conference on Georgia proposed by the French presidency and how does the current presidency of the Union intend to defend the territorial integrity of Georgia while a country recognizes two separatist regions, Abkhazia and South Ossetia?
But it is a shame that Mr. Barroso is not here because in his speech, he was not convincing, perhaps because he himself is not convinced by the proposals he made to us.
I think the financial and economic situation is much more serious than he describes it to us.
Even today, I believe that those who follow the Internet see very well that the stock markets continue to collapse despite the interventions.

For me, it is the collapse of the current system, a completely obsolete system, the system that led to bankruptcy, that led to a land being totally exploited and suffocated by greenhouse gas emissions, that led to poor development in the south and that led to poor development in our cities.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, the current financial crisis shows that when the problem is global, global action is needed.
And this is especially true in the field of agriculture or in the food sector.
This is why we have created the World Trade Organization, on which we agree, which tries to have planetized rules.

It turns out that it doesn't work quite as we would like, because we are facing a problem that is the following: we need to reconcile two things: the necessary free trade on which everyone agrees, but the equally necessary protections.
and protection of national economies or agriculture does not mean protectionism.
To do this, the path we have taken for sixty years, since the GATT, is an unbalanced path that ranges from reducing customs duties with the aim of eliminating them.
It so happens that, technically, the reduction of customs duties
It is difficult. The proof is a whole series of mathematical formulas, the South Korean formula, the European formula or the most well-known formula, the Swiss formula.
It doesn't really work because a product is not unitary.
It is composed of many elements with very different rules of origin, and reducing customs duties technically is not as simple as one might think.
We are therefore in a technical impasse and we are trying politically, through negotiations, to get out of this impasse.

However, it so happens that, technologically, scientists have invented a new customs technology, the technology of deductible customs duties, deductible by the exporter on the economy of the importing state.
In concrete terms, this deductible customs duty is transformed into a customs credit equal to the amount of the customs duty that the exporter has borne in the importing country.
This customs credit has three characters: it is repayable, negotiable and reimbursable.
It is reimbursable at the time when the exporter goes to buy from the importer, he can deduct the customs duty he has incurred.
It is negotiable because if the exporting company that has suffered 102 customs duties has nothing to buy from the importer, it negotiates it without customs credit on the stock market or in a bank.
And it is beneficial, if we want to help developing countries, for the importer to offer a customs credit amount higher than the amount of customs duties.
With this technique, we create an international trade currency whose monetary mass is equal to the amount of existing customs duties.
For example, the European Union would offer thirteen billion euros of international currency in the commercial field.
Mr. President, the Russian-Georgian conflict and the financial crisis have been an opportunity for the European Union to assert itself on the world stage as a full and first-rate political actor.
Thanks to your determination, Mr. President of the Council, Europe has managed to unite and find coordinated, effective and rapid responses.
Faced with crises, Europe proves that it exists and demonstrates its added value.
For example, when it came to immigration, everyone was no longer seasonal.
The adoption by the European Council of the Immigration and Asylum Pact, initiated by the French Presidency, constitutes a considerable step forward.
In the fight against climate change, Europe must set concrete goals and show the way to its global partners.

Mr. President of the Council, you have already expressed your opinion on this matter, but we want this agreement to be as balanced as possible, because it must take into account the economic situation of our countries, which are currently very destabilized.
But also to ask ourselves what kind of development we will choose for the future.
To meet the challenges that lie ahead, the European Union needs the Lisbon Treaty more than ever.
We understand the concerns of our Irish friends, but the status quo is not an option.
Ireland must propose a solution to us at the European Council in December, and many of us are asking for it.
In recent weeks, we have proudly observed that a strong, united political Europe in adversity, determined in the face of its partners, is listened to on the international stage.
We want this new European mentality to become the rule and to persist.
The Treaty of Lisbon is the best solution we have to achieve this.
Madam President, Minister, I was in Tbilisi when President Sarkozy came to negotiate the peace plan and, of course, I pay tribute to him for acting quickly and being able to stop this war.
But this war is a bit like our failure. We have been shy for fourteen years, we have silently witnessed the escalation of provocations in the separatist regions.

And this war, of course, has awakened Europe by placing it before its responsibilities. But the fire continues to burn in the Caucasus and we must do everything to definitively resolve the frozen conflicts for the security of all of Europe.
I also know the divisions, Minister, of European countries on Georgia's entry into NATO, and personally, I am against it.
I will make a proposal to you, I will ask the European Union to propose the neutrality status for these Caucasian countries.
Only the neutrality status will be able to ease tensions with Russia and definitively prevent this sub-region from new conflicts.
This status will ensure the security of these young democracies and contribute to our own security.
Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Minister, the last three days have been the European Development Days, where the food crisis that seriously affects the poorest countries has been discussed at length.
All the interventions emphasized the absolute necessity for developing countries to develop their own agriculture, optimally using their land and natural resources.

Incidentally, the lyrical aspects of those who yesterday and today still call for a reduction in state intervention, public spending, liberalization in all directions, privatization, and the relegation of agriculture, such as
This almost prehistoric activity, this turning point in favor of massive public investments in agricultural production and food sovereignty, was both funny and scandalous.
The future of agriculture in developing countries is directly related to the debate we are having today.

Unfortunately, I do not feel that this health check of the CAP, initiated before the outbreak of hunger riots and disastrous market disorders, takes into account the situation of the peasantry of the South and draws all the consequences of the serious ecological, social, economic and financial crises we are experiencing today.

I therefore deeply regret that the strong relationship between the farms of the North and the South is so little addressed, both in the Commission's proposals and in the Parliament's report. The questioning of the promised billion euros shows how long the road is still long.
Mr. President, the report we will vote on tomorrow marks the end of a year of work and negotiations dedicated to the future of the common agricultural policy and our farmers.
Indeed, it was on November 20th that Ms. Fischer-Bowles came to make her proposals on the health check.
After Lutz Goebbels'progress report, here comes the Capulasantos report on the Commission's proposal.
We must congratulate our two colleagues for their excellent work.
The European Parliament's Committee on Agriculture was able to stand firm in the face of the Commission's initial proposals, which we deemed far too liberal.
I will remain vigilant with regard to the dairy sector and in particular the measures preceding the abolition of quotas.

I am thinking in particular of mountain milk producers, who should not be the poor parents of this reform, and we must be careful not to leave them aside, because they will need to be supported more than others.
I don't want to play the Cassandra, but how can we imagine the French dairy industry grouped into one and the same region?
It is therefore with kindness that I welcome the proposal to set up a milk fund, which consists of evaluating the increase in milk quotas as early as 2010, depending on the evolution of the market.

The calculation of the gradual modulation made by the Agriculture Commission seems fair to me and would allow us to strengthen the development of territories, rural areas and to preserve biodiversity in a sustainable way.
I also welcome the clarification of eco-conditionality, the implementation of which has been a real puzzle for farmers until now.

I also want us to keep the amount of the tobacco fund, which allows us to keep our small farms and a significant workforce in Europe, in a region where nothing else is exploitable, and which allows us to avoid import products.
Finally, Minister, we greatly appreciated your commitment throughout these negotiations.
You have shown a lot of patience and determination, and you have not counted your time, far from it.
It was a real pleasure to work with you.
You will have been very effective with us.
I know we can count on
Mr. President, first of all, thank you for the work done and for the conclusions and guidelines proposed by the CAP health check of Mr. Capullo Santos'report.
Agriculture is indeed an economic sector that cannot respond to simple market signals.
Its activity has impacts on food self-sufficiency, but also, as is too often forgotten, on territories and employment.
The removal of market instruments would be a serious blow to our agriculture.
For example, decoupling poses a real difficulty for some breeding territories, such as breeding cows and sheep, and I am pleased to have heard Mrs. Fischer-Boll speak on this issue just now.
Moreover, it is clear that strictly maintaining historical references would put a huge brake on any possibility of reform.
However, I still believe that the issue of the second pillar of the CAP is an essential issue because rural areas need to rely on agricultural activity to develop employment in rural areas.
And so we must think about this second-pillar issue without, of course, amputating the first.
Since Minister Jouyet is going to leave us, I think this Parliament should thank him.
He was one of the most diligent ministers we have known.
I wish him good luck.

Madam President, I voted for the Perry report on the integration of the CMO twenty into the single CMO, I must say, with a death in my soul, because I believe that this single CMO is not a simplification and does not increase transparency.
It will make life more complicated for winegrowers and the entire wine industry.
Yesterday evening, the Commissioner tried to reassure us
I hope the Commission will keep its word and that, above all, the profession will still be adequately represented in the advisory committee, as has been the case since the first CMO.
Mister.
Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, our group enthusiastically supports the draft Small Business Act presented to us by the Commission last June.

Certainly, as early as the year two thousand, initiatives were taken towards SMEs, and I am thinking in particular of the excellent work of our colleague Dominique Blasto on the SME charter, initiatives that were appreciated but deemed insufficient because they often remained in the state of pious wishes.
Today, we must go further.
The serious economic crisis that our countries are going through and whose consequences are particularly worrying for SMEs invites us to do so if necessary.
In this regard, the Small Business Act is part of a new, resolutely proactive approach.
In a few weeks, we will examine Mrs. Herzog's report on the Commission's communication, but today, through the submission of this oral question, we wanted to address the Council.

Mr. Minister, we have taken note with interest of the conclusions adopted yesterday by the Competitiveness Council and we would like to know if the European Council of the next eleven and twelve December
It will relay its conclusions well and give a strong impetus so that the great guiding principle Think small first is quickly transposed into the regulatory framework of the member states.
We want the Council to commit to the principle of the annexed action plan, accompanied by concrete measures.
In this regard, and in the short time I have, I will emphasize three directions in which we need binding impulses.
Impact studies, which should be systematic, and regular monitoring, with the European Parliament's control of the state of application of the Small Business Act in the Member States,
access to the public market,
The code of good conduct has no binding scope, we must be more imaginative, more inventive, and propose concrete, adapted measures that really open up access to these markets for SMEs.
Finally, access to financing, more essential than ever in the current context,
Your proposals are good, Minister, they must also include supply support.
There is an urgency.
Thank you for assuring us of the Council's will.

Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Commissioner, we all know that SMEs are the backbone of the European Union, since they employ more than seventy percent of the European Union's workforce and represent ninety-nine percent of European companies.

But as has already been said, these millions of small and medium-sized enterprises are now worried and threatened by the financial crisis because it degrades the purchasing power and household confidence, and affects the order books.

It is therefore the treasury of SMEs that is in danger, and it is therefore necessary to ensure that their activities are supported by ensuring that banks guarantee effective access to the necessary financing for the continuity of their operation.
This is the whole issue of the conclusions of the Competitiveness Council of December 1st, which the Minister spoke about, and the recovery plan approved by the European finance ministers.
Making the needs of SMEs a permanent political priority of the Union is essential, and I would like to welcome the action plan in favor of the Small Business Act for Europe.
It reflects the desire to ensure the effective application of the guiding principle, to give priority to the small first, that is to say to European SMEs.
However, as the Commissioner said and as we all say, the Council must really engage with the other institutions
European. For this principle to be effective now, we must go beyond the framework of the declaration and move on to implementation in all European policies and programs.
However, we can say that this action plan is a real response to the urgency of the situation.
And I would like to welcome the voluntarism of the French Presidency of the Union, which has made it possible to quickly translate intentions into actions.
Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, I fully support the rapporteur, who defends the position that was ours at first reading, a position rejected by the governments of the Member States.
It was urgent to bring our legislation on on-call time into line with the case law of the Court of Justice, and this has been done.
The CERCAS report provides balanced and protective answers for employees.
All on-call time is counted as working time.
Compensatory rest occurs immediately after the service period.
It is a matter of common sense to guarantee decent working conditions, particularly for the medical professions.
But the reform of the Working Time Directive also gives us the opportunity to advance our European social law by abolishing the individual opt-out.
The Cercas report seizes this opportunity and proposes a gradual elimination of any possibility of derogation from the maximum legal duration of working time.
We must face reality.
It is a joke to say that the employee is on an equal footing with his employer and can refuse what is offered to him.
Dear colleagues, we must clearly show the governments of the member states that the text they want to impose on us is unacceptable.

In the concert of praise that will certainly ring the ears of the French government tomorrow, it seems necessary to focus first and foremost on employees who will be called upon to work more and more without really having a choice, and this, like all those who will be asked to work in France on Sunday tomorrow.
It is, moreover, clearly to open up this possibility that the French government has changed its view on the individual opt-out in the Council.

My dear colleagues, let us listen to the employees and try to respond to their call, if we do not want the negative votes of the French, Dutch and Irish referendums to be followed by many others, calling into question a European Union that would give them the feeling that they are not dealing with their daily problems. Thank you.
Mr. President, it was a very beautiful French presidency.
There were very few dissenting voices to not agree.
The twenty-seven have gone beyond their differences to reach a series of exemplary decisions.
On the energy and climate package, Europe is taking a first step, and in this regard, this first step is immense.
It now has the means to assume its environmental responsibility without sacrificing its economy.
It can now take the lead in this matter, to lead other continents on the path of sustainable development.
Moreover, Ireland proposes a scenario to get out of its isolation.
Our Irish friends will once again vote on the Lisbon Treaty, with all the cards in their hands, since almost all the other members have finally voted.
Current crises show us that the Union needs the best institutional tools to be effective more than ever.
The European Council has adopted a massive and coordinated economic recovery plan, based on long-term productive investment and targeted support for the industrial sectors most severely affected.
President Sarkozy raised the issue of reducing certain VAT rates, and I fully share his point of view.
Let us hope that the ministers of economy and finance will reach an agreement in March, which seemed impossible to the heads of state and government last weekend.
The challenges that Europeans are facing give the Union the opportunity to show itself to be more united, more reactive, and more concerned with protecting them.
We are grateful to the French Presidency for instilling this new dynamism.
We, like Nicolas Sarkozy, want to avoid repeating yesterday's councils, which ended at four in the morning to negotiate three peanuts.
Over the past six months, Europe has indeed changed its mentality, scope, and credibility.
We must thank the French Presidency for this, and we are well aware that it is not entirely foreign to us. Thank you, Mr. President.
The situation in Gaza is known to everyone.
What we are discussing here in Parliament is natural.
But we ask that the Security Council take a stand, we ask that the authorities take a stand, that the European Union take a stand, and we in Parliament discuss and do not want to take a stand.

I think that, given the urgency of the situation in Gaza, it is of the utmost importance that this Parliament speaks out and says exactly what it wants to stop the massacres that are taking place in the Middle East at the moment.
I find it unacceptable that this Parliament does not have the courage and lucidity to vote on a resolution after our debate.
That is why our group is asking for the decision of the Conference of Presidents to be revised and for the debate that we must end.
We will have to deal with the situation in Gaza through a resolution that will demonstrate the clear and firm position of this Parliament, of a majority, to stop the massacres in Gaza.

We want a resolution, we must be aware that we have a political responsibility in the face of what is happening, and this political responsibility cannot simply be a discussion, it must be a resolution that clearly says what we want and what we denounce.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, more than ever, the proposal for a directive that the Parliament is about to vote on arouses in me a very mixed feeling.
It is true that the rapporteur, Mr Klintz, has been working hard for years and has negotiated with talent, particularly during the trialogue.

It is also true that the directive has made a number of significant progress towards a better functioning of the internal market and the collective management of financial assets, which is welcomed as such by the European investment fund industry.

However, the debates and discussions in the Council and Parliament have never been entirely free, since the results were known in advance. For some actors, it was necessary, at all costs, to introduce the European passport for management companies.
In principle, there is nothing to repeat, the passport is perfectly defended. However, it is necessary to ensure that the introduction of the passport for management companies
This is accompanied by the necessary guarantees, particularly in terms of the supervision of funds, since it leads to a dissociation of functions beyond borders.
However, I regret to note that the system in place is not only complex, but also subject to divergent interpretations.
They risk very quickly facing practical difficulties that will harm the European industry, particularly exports to third countries.
I have taken note that my position is in the minority, but I do not feel uncomfortable.
Normally, I would have been tempted to say that only practice will allow us to draw definitive conclusions on this matter and thus determine
Who is right between those who trust the adaptability of market players and those who stick to a more cautious approach?
It is not excluded that success will be over, but on the other hand, nothing guarantees it either.
However, the very recent news, particularly the Madoff scandal and its implications for the collective asset management industry, is not to reassure us.
Skepticism is followed by my concern.
The investment fund industry will not be spared by the financial crisis, we can see it right now.
It may be necessary to fundamentally question this crisis context.

The fact that in this context of deep crisis, we make choices that dilute the responsibilities of the actors or that presuppose perfect cooperation between supervisory authorities can really be considered incongruous.
I tell you this as I think this directive is also from a period preceding the crisis.
It is marked by a certain carelessness.
Indeed, the financial system is going through a lasting and fundamental crisis of confidence, entire parts of its architecture must be rethought.

Let us not forget the primary function of OPCMs, which is to protect the investor by diversifying risks and establishing strict rules. By voting on this text as it stands, without really knowing where we are going, we are acting as if nothing had happened.
This autism does not announce anything good, which is why I will abstain, even though I signed the compromise amendments negotiated with the Council.
Given the circumstances, the improvements made seem to me to be of little weight compared to the issues of principle that I have just explained.

Mr. President, although the regulation on animal welfare has been in force since January 2007, it seems that the Member States are not systematically enforcing the rules by providing, as they were asked to do, annual reports.
Therefore, a global analysis remains random, since many elements are missing as to the means put in place to carry out inspections.
As a member of animal protection associations and animal welfare intergroup, this subject is of particular concern to me.
Associations have been fighting desperately for decades to finally establish directives in this area in 2007, where we see that the Member States show a certain laxity.
I would even dare say a certain bad will, because, after all, we know that the implementation of controls and inspections is absolutely not insurmountable.
We know the slaughtering sites, we know the breeding sites, we know the cattle transit routes. So, where is the problem?

I believe it is important, in our time, when public opinion is increasingly aware of animal welfare, whether it is in terms of breeding, slaughter or transportation conditions, that states respect these feelings.

Since I have been given the floor, I would like to add, regarding transport, that it would be essential to consider and take into account, regardless of transport durations, local climatic conditions.
Indeed, a transport of several hours in the Netherlands in the spring is nothing comparable to the same transport time in the middle of summer in a country such as Greece.
Shouldn't night transport be imposed in these cases?
Thank you for considering this proposal in the future.

Mr. President, I am glad that it was a Brit, our colleague Parish, who submitted this text, saying that two thousand years ago, the Roman soldiers did well to go to Great Britain and bring amphorums of olive oil and wine.
But then we will have to draw consequences.

It is not very reasonable, symbolically, to move the Food Agency to Helsinki, and it is not reasonable that the European Commission does not go back on the following points: first, to re-establish aid for the starving, then to stop the

Stop the attacks against olive trees, particularly in Andalusia and throughout Europe, stop the attacks against bluefin tuna fishermen in the Mediterranean and stop the attacks against European vineyards with the tearing down of the seeds.
I suggest to our commissioner, our president, Mr. Barroso, to organize a big banquet in Portugal with sheep cheeses and wine.
We have all indeed advocated for the closure of Guantanamo and we are all pleased with President Obama's decision to close this prison of shame.
Today, the question of welcoming Guantanamo detainees should not be asked of us.
As Europeans, faithful to our values of defending human rights, we must take our responsibilities, because it is our duty to welcome these former detainees.
And we were able to read, and here I turn to the Council, we were able to read in the press that the member states were not very warm for this reception.
Here, I would really like to appeal to the Council and, in particular, to the reluctant member states to accept these detainees on their territory.
And I would say, dear colleagues, that the worst thing would be if the nice help caused by the closure of Guantanamo got bogged down because we would not have responded when we called on Europe.

This is important because the European animal feed sector is one of the most important sectors of agriculture, both in terms of production, since it represents half of the agricultural production in the European Union, one hundred and twenty million tons, and in terms of turnover, about fifty billion euros.
The European Union has five million breeders and sixty million households with pets.

In the past, the European Union had to manage a number of health crises, which means that today we must be more vigilant about transparency to meet the expectations of breeders, but also of consumers.

The provisions provided in this report have the advantage of representing a minimal cost for industries and a great benefit for consumers, who are increasingly attentive to the quality of the products they buy.
The adoption of this report will limit risks by guaranteeing better product quality, better control, better traceability and a wide range of information for the breeder and, ultimately, the consumer.
Today, with the increase in international trade, it is more than imperative to strengthen all prevention mechanisms so that the food crises we have experienced in the past do not happen again.

This report manages to reconcile the right to information while strictly defining the nutritional elements that must be included on the labels and the right to intellectual property, which is so important for preserving the competitiveness of our industries.

I think that manufacturers must indeed be required to immediately notify the use of any new raw material entering the composition of animal feed in order to guarantee transparency and facilitate control by the competent authorities.
The fact of including an emergency procedure that allows a new dangerous substance to be introduced into the list of prohibited substances seems to me to be absolutely essential.

Similarly, giving the breeder the possibility to question the competent national authority or the European Commission in case of doubt about an unfair claim allows the system to be better verified, both to protect the customer while preserving the loyalty of commercial transactions.

I would like to express my full support for this excellent report, because experience shows that regulation on animal feed labelling, I conclude, Mr. President, by prioritizing quality, transparency, traceability and control is the best guarantee to prevent new health crises in Europe.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, it is certainly not Europe, and even less its High Representative for Foreign Policy, Javier Solana, former NATO Secretary General, who can play the role of mediator between Israel and the Palestinians.
At most, are they called upon to finance the reconstruction of the Gaza Strip, as they do today for Kosovo, Lebanon or Afghanistan?
Americans and Israelis are bombing, Europeans are financing reconstruction.
This is the distribution of tasks among allies.
But it should be the destroyers who pay.
Egypt is at the center of the peace talks, which concern a prolonged ceasefire with Hamas.

But the challenge to be met is formidable, as the new Israeli government, under pressure from the third man, Liberman, the leader of a far right that is democratically accepted there, risks seeing its task singularly complicated in this negotiation.
Indeed, Netanyahu, who is presented as the future Prime Minister, has always opposed a truce with Hamas.
Another difficulty is that the Palestinian Authority of Mahmoud Abbas has become a sort of international protectorate in the West Bank, whose legitimacy has greatly decreased with the population.

The last element to be taken into account is the expansion of Israeli settlements, which has never ceased since 1967, making the creation of a Palestinian state in the West Bank particularly delicate.
Today, the ball is in the Israeli camp, but do the falcons in both camps accept this truce of God that both parties are demanding without giving themselves the means?
Let me add a reflection on the reintegration of France into the integrated military structure of NATO, which will come up for debate with the Vatanen report.
This reintegration will lead to severe obligations for France.
Indeed, we are reintegrating NATO, even though the Cold War has been over since 1990.
Sarkozy seems to have forgotten the fall of the Berlin Wall and Russia's return to the ranks of free nations.
Should the logic of blocs be strengthened at a time when the multipolarization and growth of emerging countries, including in military terms, are increasing?
Moreover, France's accession to the integrated structure will force it to strengthen its contingent in Afghanistan, whereas it already has three men on the ground.
With what budget will it finance, when its defense budget will fall below two percent of GDP and more than thirty regiments will be eliminated?
Paradoxically, we will increase our budgetary participation to integrate NATO and at the same time reduce our military presence in Africa.
European defense, dear to President Sarkozy, will therefore be a pillar of the Atlantic Alliance.
It was enough to read the Treaty of Lisbon and its additional protocols to be convinced.
Whether it is in terms of foreign policy or common security, the European path is a dead end that will only lead to alignment with the Americans and their allies.
It is this logic of erasure that we reject in the name of national sovereignty and independence, based in particular on our autonomous nuclear deterrent force.
Madam President, I congratulate our three rapporteurs for this remarkable summary they have made of the current state of our common foreign and security policy.

Mr. High Representative, you know better than anyone else that Europe is expected today on the world stage to take the place assigned to it by its economic and demographic power and the wealth of its democratic and humanist values.

It is clear that despite the will regularly expressed by more than two thirds of our European fellow citizens, as you said, some progress has been made, I agree with you, over the past ten years, but it is clear that this Europe still does not exist.
If it were necessary to illustrate its recent erasure in the solution of the new drama in the Middle East, I would be here to demonstrate it.
There was and still is a need for a European presence in Gaza to play an active role, both in helping the survival of the populations and in the reconstruction of the
countries and in the fight against arms smuggling, which had allowed this territory to be transformed into a base for launching missiles of all caliber.
Despite the good words spoken to Charmelshire and Jerusalem, nothing has been done in this regard yet.

I am repeating a question already asked during the Lebanese crisis: When can we, Mr. High Representative, hope for the deployment of a European fleet in the Mediterranean, as we have put one in the face of piracy?
We have the means.
Will we ever have the will?
Well, Commissioner, Mr. President, my dear colleagues, the decision of the Parliament to accept the urgency requested by the Council for
The handling of this file was unanimous both in the Fisheries Committee last week and this morning here in plenary.
We are all aware of the need for the European Union to honor the commitments made in Marrakech last November by the competent international commission, the ICCTA.
The aim is to implement the recommendations adopted by this organization in order to stop the persistent phenomenon of overfishing of bluefin tuna in the
Atlantic East and in the Mediterranean, and to face the serious dangers that arise for the future of the species and therefore that of the fishery itself.
Two of our colleagues from the Fisheries Committee, Mrs. Fraga and Mr. Romeva i Rueda, were present in Marrakech and will speak about it in the context of this debate.
I would like to recall the importance that our committee attaches to this file, which involves the main dimensions of the common fisheries policy, namely the management of
resources, fleet management, compliance with international, regional and bilateral agreements, technical measures and, above all, control, I will come back to this later.
This characteristic file is therefore a test in our eyes of the credibility of this common fisheries policy.
For this reason, it was obviously not a question of the implementation of the new recovery plan being done without the consultation of the European Parliament.
I am therefore pleased that the Commission has finally chosen the only legally and politically acceptable way to implement the
recommendations of the CCTA, namely a proposal for a regulation in due form, based on article thirty-seven of the treaty.

The transposition into Community law of commitments made by the Commission on behalf of the European Union in regional fisheries organisations is not, in fact, a trivial operation, and we insist that it always be carried out under the democratic control of our institution.
In essence, I welcome the various proposed measures, which, although binding for our operators, are up to the challenges, and I would like to stress that the most important ones are the
Important of these measures are certainly those that concern control, because it is true that without control, no recovery plan can be effective.
Thank you, Commissioner, for this proposal, and I invite you to show all the more determination.
determination in the concrete implementation of the plan, once it has been endorsed by the Council, that you have put into the conclusion of a satisfactory agreement at the level of the ICCTA.
Madam President, Commissioner, I regret that the Council and the Commission have not yet undertaken to define territorial cohesion in a concrete way.
The French Presidency has tried and I would like to welcome this initiative.
Our Parliament continues to insist that this objective be applicable as soon as the Lisbon Treaty comes into force and that its contours be clarified as soon as possible.

Like Mr van Nistelrooy's excellent report, I hope that territorial cohesion will become the legal basis guaranteeing the harmonious development of all territories of the Union and allowing the best possible use of the characteristics specific to each European region.
It is essential to better coordinate Community policies in order to maximize the impact of interventions on the ground.
Territorial cohesion is not intended to exclusively target regions with permanent disabilities.
It must nonetheless focus on the polycentric development of the European Union as a whole, taking into account the characteristics of each territory, while preserving their diversity.
This new concept seems relevant to me for taking into account the outermost regions in order to ensure sustainable and balanced growth for them.

In this regard, I would like to thank the rapporteur for having included in his compromise amendments my requests regarding the specific challenges faced by the outermost regions in terms of accessibility and competitiveness, which are essential elements of territorial cohesion.
Reading the Commission's recent communication entitled The Outermost Regions an asset for Europe, it seems to me that it wants to apply to the outermost regions all the
recommendations on improving governance in the field of cohesion, thus making the Outermost Regions the first illustration, somewhat anticipated, of the implementation of territorial cohesion.

I hope that the overseas states, which will soon start in France, will proceed in the same way and largely integrate the major territorial impact of European policies in favor of the outermost regions, whose added value is undeniable.
and uncontested.
We have fun reading the conclusions of the presidency of the last Council.
It resembles the victory communiqu of all the armies in disarray.
They are derisory, even in the repeated statement that, once the crisis is over, the EU will build a stronger economy for the future, or in the reaffirmation of a Lisbon strategy in full swing.
Thus, as they lock themselves in their glass tower, Eurocrats, Europhiles and all kinds of Europhobes end up no longer taking the measure of things.
Everyone knows that the Eurozone was the first to enter a recession, after having experienced the lowest inflation rate in the world for eight years.
But it is also the one that is experiencing the greatest difficulties in terms of its industrial competitiveness and employment situation.
Especially, it is the one that, through the general disarmament of the natural defense taken away from nations, is the least armed to react.
In reality, the only merit of this crisis will be to wake up the people, robbed of the facilities of financial anticipation and anti-national propaganda.
Only states will have the legitimate instruments necessary for any major action, and they will have to push the EU and the euro straps forward.
For the French, in any case, it is increasingly clear that there will be no salvation without France, no France without French policy, no French policy without national and popular sovereignty.

Madam President, I believe that the issue of distributing food to the most disadvantaged is indeed very timely, but I believe that, at its core, the Commission's proposal does not correspond to the problem.
The issue of co-financing makes me wonder, and I think that it is rather the issue of liberalism that has led to the evaluations of the CAP in recent years that needs to be questioned.
Hunger riots and abrupt price fluctuations are permanent indicators of the limits of the liberalization of agricultural markets.
This liberalization has always been at the expense of fragile populations, fragile producers and fragile territories.

I therefore advocate that politics regain its rights, regain control, both at the European and global levels, and that the strategic field of agriculture and food, of men, both from a quantitative and qualitative point of view, is not subject to the strict laws of the market.
Of course, there is an urgency, and the Sikerski report responds to this urgency, and I welcome it, but I would like, as part of the reflection that is opening up on
In the future of the CAP, it should be recalled that the priority objective is to structurally combat hunger and poverty, which we know in all member states and in the world.
Rural areas are available to meet food needs through sufficient and quality production, but they will still need to be given the financial and human means to ensure this heavy responsibility.
Mr. President, in this period of economic recession, it was important that the European Union continued to show its solidarity with developing countries.
Let us recall that in 2007, the European Community and the Member States contributed together sixty percent of the total development aid, making the European Union the world's leading donor.
European development funds help fight poverty while promoting economic development and democracy.

I am therefore pleased that for the ACP countries, a budget of twenty-three billion euros has been allocated for the period 2008-2013 under the tenth EDF, which represents almost double the amount foreseen for the ninth EDF.
In its report, the Court of Auditors concludes that the accounts of the 7th, 8th and 9th EDF are generally faithful, legal and regular.
We can only be pleased with the record levels of execution of contracts and payments in the implementation of the EDF.
However, I also note that progress must be made to strengthen the control and surveillance system, as there is still a significant level of errors affecting certain transactions.
Similarly, there is a risk that is too often high in terms of budget support, and in my opinion, these risks should be better assessed.
In this regard, I share the idea that budgetary support should only be granted if the beneficiary country has the capacity to manage the funds in a transparent, responsible and effective manner.

Among the priorities we must work on in the future, I would like to mention the integration of the EDF into the general budget, I will conclude, of the Community, as this would strengthen the effectiveness and transparency of development aid.

In conclusion, Mr. President, I would also like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, the representatives of the Court, but also all the staff of the Commission who have done an excellent job on the ground, and I obviously regret the absence of the Council, and in particular of the Czech Presidency.
Madam President, the Parliament and its rapporteur were forced to reject a bad compromise, and they were right to do so.
Our delegation remained faithful to the position adopted very widely in plenary, which called for the abolition of any derogation from the legal duration of work in the long term.
But the truth is that the Parliament was the only one who wanted to move things forward.
The representatives of the European people had decided, far beyond partisan divisions, to end this archaic thing called the opt-out.
We were the only ones to propose a real compromise text that the Council of Ministers ignored superbly, just like the Commission, by the way.
The Council and the Commission have aligned themselves with the position of those who fiercely oppose any progress in workers'rights in Europe.
Mr. President of the Council, it is clear that you have reached your goal.
The Court of Justice forces you to consider all on-call time as working time, so you have not lost anything on that side.
The opt-out you want still exists in practice, so the immobilist won.
More than ever, the MEPs elected next June will have to fight towards harmonization of social standards from above.
Ah, sir.

Mr. President, this is certainly not on behalf of the LIBE Committee, but probably on behalf of my group. I would like to take this brief minute to express my extraordinarily positive assessment of Mrs. Paganova's report.
Congratulations, Madam, on your report.

I believe that by writing this report, you have drawn up an extraordinarily precise specification of elements that should be well included, Commissioner, in the Stockholm Programme, which I know the Commission is actively preparing.

Let me add to everything that has been said regarding the importance of training magistrates, the importance of evaluation, and to emphasize two fundamental elements of mutual trust that are at the basis of what could be mutual recognition tomorrow.
One, the independence of justice.
There are currently a number of countries in the Union in which the independence of justice in relation to political power or other powers is not established.
This is a scandal and it must stop.
Secondly, procedural guarantees.

As long as we are not sure that in a number of countries, people suspected or accused of having committed certain types of crimes benefit from procedural guarantees similar to those that exist in other countries, it is difficult to widely accept the principle of mutual recognition.
This is a fundamental element and I wanted to introduce it in this debate.
Congratulations, Mrs. Pagano.
Madam President, we cannot remain silent about the situation in Madagascar, and we will not be the only ones to condemn this situation.
The African Union, the Southern African Development Community, the International Organization of the Francophonie, the Inter-Parliamentary Union, the European Union at the Commission's word,

The USA, a large number of countries, including mine and Norway, to speak of countries on the European continent, have condemned the coup, because it must be called a cat a cat, which took place in Madagascar.
We cannot remain silent and we are asking for a return to constitutional legality.
We never ask for a return to the starting point, with, if necessary, arbitration by the Malagasy people through a consultation, in the form of a presidential election or a referendum.
It is up to the assemblies and political leaders of Madagascar to determine the most effective form of consultation.
So, what we are asking for with this joint resolution is to add our voice to that of the international community to clearly signal to those who have taken power in a completely non-democratic way.

democratic and in the form of a coup, no matter how dressed it is, to return to the constitutional legality of Madagascar, which is one of the guarantors of the future development of this great island of the Indian Ocean.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would like to thank Commissioner Dimas for his presence and his responses, and for the attention he continues to pay to all these disasters.
We worked together a lot when President Barroso asked me to prepare a report, which he also mentioned, on the creation of a European civil protection force.
I presented this report on May 9, 2006.
When I re-read it and see all the disasters that have occurred, I think it is still relevant.
Mrs. Zavella, of course, it is not just Greece.
All countries are concerned. I would add that it is not only natural disasters, but also human disasters due to men.
I am thinking of maritime disasters, Erika and many others, industrial accidents like Chernobyl.
There are other natural disasters than fires.
I think of the tsunami.
We can fear one day a tsunami in the Mediterranean, like the one that occurred at the beginning of the 20th century, which completely destroyed the city of Messina.
Frankly, Commissioner, my dear colleagues, the tools we are mobilizing are not up to these disasters that will multiply under the double effect of global warming and transport.
And that is why I think we need to be more ambitious.
I thank the Commission, Commissioner Dimas, all his teams, the Directorate General that are running the civil protection mechanism.
I think we need to go further.
With the member countries that wish to do so, we can imagine enhanced cooperation.
If we are not twenty-seven to create this civil protection force, let's start with twelve or fifteen.
And then you will see that it will concern everyone.
When I make the list of disasters, I can say that everyone is concerned: the floods that affected Germany in two thousand and two, and even the major pandemics, as well as terrorism.
That is why I would like the Commission to take the initiative to go further, to propose to the Member States to go further.
Our Parliament, the Environment Committee, the Defence and Security Committee will support you in these proactive initiatives.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this summer, the Mediterranean forest was the prey of flames in Marseille, in southern Corsica, but also in Italy, Spain and, on a larger scale, in Greece.
More than four hundred hectares of forests and fields have gone up in smoke, causing considerable material debates, irreparable damage to biodiversity, as well as dramatic losses in human lives.
Concerned by this repeated review year after year and aware of the multiplier effect of global warming on fires,
I call for European awareness, for better coordination of efforts and for pooling firefighting resources.
I wish to see the implementation of a vast Euro-Mediterranean cooperation project to combat forest fires within the framework of the Union for the Mediterranean.
I welcome the existing initiatives, including the European forest fire information system, pilot projects,
I call for a reform of the European Union Solidarity Fund so that it becomes an effective tool for responding to crises and a strengthening of the European force of
protection and the Euro aid mechanism, conceived by Michel Barnier as early as 2006 to intervene on the territory of the twenty-seven member countries as well as abroad.

I think that one of the keys to the problem of forest fires lies in the exchange of knowledge and good practices in prevention, and I would like to point out the pioneering role played by forestry experts in my own department.
And I can, of course, make this example available to Europe, which can serve.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, I will be brief.
I think there are two elements in this debate.
The conjunctural question is how to get out of this crisis?
All measures that go both to help farmers and to intervention measures are necessary and absolutely necessary.
They need to be supported and even considered to be more important.
This is what we are proposing with a number of colleagues here in Parliament.
Secondly, there is a question structurally raised about the management of the milk market, and this is where there is a divergence with you, Commissioner.
You propose to move in the direction of contractualization.
I tell you in advance that contractualizing between industrialists and farmers, in the long run, while the industries are competitive with each other, will lead to competition at the European level.
We need public regulation to regulate a market.
There is no other alternative.
This is where the debate will have to begin after this crisis.
I think that in this debate, we must respect all opinions and all options, and I fear that we have gone too quickly at the time of the health check to settle an issue like quotas.

So far, I say to all those who have spoken, they have allowed both to maintain dairy production in Europe, to ensure an extremely developed dairy industry and at the same time to ensure a price for consumers that has been quite bearable so far. Thank you, Commissioner.
Mr. President, a few days after the positive referendum in Ireland, I really feel that we can say that we are more European today than before.
I am really, fully, serenely happy about it.
Unfortunately, we are still essentially dependent on the decision of the Constitutional Court, but also on the goodwill of the Czech president.

A clear signal of accountability must be sent to those who hold the future of this treaty, which is crucial for the Union, for our institutions and for the five hundred million Europeans we represent.
We can no longer be hostages of a few whose only goal is to counteract the European general interest.
If it is legitimate that some people do not want to go further in European integration, if it is legitimate to express these reluctances, it is also legitimate to let those who want to progress.
Generally, the processes of ratifying European treaties too often take the form of saga or a victory over the pirus.
Are we doomed to constantly have to push to guarantee the implementation of a treaty and its institutional reforms?
We will have to learn from this chaotic ratification process and, of course, from this commitment to negotiation with a view to organizing a second

The referendum in Ireland, as if it were normal to have a people who expressed themselves in a sovereign manner vote again, and as if it were normal that an assent to a treaty could be a bargaining chip.
The coherence and institutional balance of the European adventure are at stake.
Ratifying a treaty is a minimum requirement of loyalty and cohesion from the moment one chooses that one's country joins the European Union.
We wanted to give a strong signal to the citizens by ratifying the treaty for the European elections in June 2009.
What do you think the citizen thinks of the Lisbon Treaty today, beyond our internal coherence and our legitimacy?
Mr. President, my speech is about the deterioration of working conditions in Europe.
Today, nearly half of the workers in the world earn less than two dollars a day.
Twelve point three million people are still subjected to slavery and more than two hundred million children are forced to work.
In Europe, the number of poor workers is increasing day by day, and the International Labour Organization reports one hundred and sixty deaths every year due to a lack of prevention.
In this context, I would like to emphasize our responsibility towards all those who are deprived of jobs and social rights, who work in unworthy conditions.
Of these millions of workers who suffer morally and physically, sometimes driven to suicide or victims of cancer or chronic illnesses due to their working conditions.
It is time to move away from the religion of working more, from the race for profit, to short-term competition.
The right to decent work and the strengthening of the right to work must be at the top of the Union's priorities in the next ten years.
Madam President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, a challenge for humanity, a challenge for future generations.

To raise the glove, Copenhagen must allow for a global agreement, a single agreement, as our president of the environment commission, Jolainen, said earlier. An alliance of all industrialized countries and emerging countries is necessary.

Today, with our debate, but also with the drafting of a resolution by our Parliament, we call once again on the European Union to maintain its leading role in this necessary policy to combat climate change.
Let us remember that we must speak with one voice to maintain our credibility.
Yes, we must reach an agreement in Copenhagen to limit the increase in the global average temperature to a level that does not exceed two degrees above pre-industrial levels.
Yes, we must sign an agreement in Copenhagen in order to achieve collective reductions in greenhouse gas emissions by thirty percent by 2020 compared to 1990.
But that will not be enough.
It is not only necessary for developed countries to significantly reduce their emissions, but also for developing countries to contribute to achieving the objectives.

Industrialized countries must therefore provide sufficient, sustainable and predictable financial and technical support to developing countries to encourage them to commit to reducing their greenhouse gas emissions.
Copenhagen must thus allow developing countries to evolve towards carbon-saving models.
So, let me address two areas that seem necessary to me for our future.
First of all, the establishment at the global level of funding to combat global warming based on the taxation of financial transactions.
Then, it seems necessary to me to implement a tax adjustment at the borders of Europe that would affect imports of products manufactured without the slightest concern for environmental protection.

a contractualization and reversal to the countries of the South of the carbon tax thus collected at the borders of Europe, which would serve to finance investments in the equipment necessary to fight against global warming.

Mr. President, I would like to intervene in the same vein as my intervention yesterday on the preparation of the Copenhagen summit and, moreover, following yesterday's ECOFIN meeting, which was not successful.
I questioned you about the responsibility we, as industrialized countries, had to ensure that developing countries could follow us in our efforts to combat climate change.
In Copenhagen, we cannot pretend that we all have the same capabilities, otherwise it would mean that we all start from the same point to finally achieve nothing.
To convince our development partners to join us, we will obviously have to address the issue of the aid that must be granted to them and not wait for the outcome of the Copenhagen summit.
At the next European Council, the twenty-seven will absolutely have to agree on how the European Union designs aid to developing countries in the important context of climate change.
Yesterday, as I said, the Ecofin Council of Finance Ministers failed to find a common position on this issue.
However, we know that this issue is absolutely central.
The European Commission had already made proposals, and I absolutely want us to take the lead in leading our partners towards the necessary global solidarity to overcome this climate change problem.
I would like to welcome the efforts of the Swedish Presidency to reach an ambitious agreement in Copenhagen, despite the very strong wind of pessimism blowing over these future negotiations.
For my part, I think it is not realistic to admit at this stage that the Copenhagen summit is dead or that it will not lead to a conclusive agreement to be ratified by all parties.
Let's not give in too quickly to pessimism.
I am advocating that at this stage, we do not lower our ambitions, neither in terms of objectives nor in terms of deadlines.
We must continue to believe in a comprehensive, ambitious and binding global political agreement, paving the way for the conclusion of a legal treaty as soon as possible.
It is really too early to mention the deadline for the sixteenth COP in December 2010.
We must now translate our rhetoric into real political will.
We need to clarify our commitment in terms of financial and aid to developing countries, particularly in terms of technology transfer.
At this stage, a total and collective commitment from the European Union is essential.

I also note on paper the recent but exemplary momentum given to the talks by Brazil, South Korea, Indonesia and Norway, in particular, which have quantified their ambitions to reduce their polluting emissions.

If we can understand the flexibility demanded by the United States, which is only just starting to take into account the climate issue, we must still achieve quantifiable, binding and ambitious commitments in the short, medium and long term from other major polluters, such as the United States and China.
Otherwise, we will run into climate, political and moral disasters.
Madam President, we all know and have all said it, the importance of the Copenhagen negotiations, but if we all hope for an agreement, we cannot accept an agreement at any price.
If the conditions for an ambitious agreement are not met, I very clearly want the European Union to be able to say no and refuse to sign a discount agreement.
The European populations we represent here are waiting for an agreement, an agreement that will allow us to effectively fight against all the climate disruptions we see around us every day.
They will not be satisfied with announcements, declarations of intent that are not quantified, or non-binding objectives that can be wiped off once the media spotlight is turned off.

In Copenhagen, the states will have to commit. The European Union, the only continent that has seen its CO2 emissions decrease since 1990, the only continent that has made precise, binding and ambitious commitments for the future, cannot bear the burden of the effort alone.

This is why, if other industrialized and emerging countries do not want to take their share of the burden, we will have to draw all the consequences by establishing a tax at our borders that protects our industry from the competition of those who would decide not to participate in a global agreement.
We Europeans ask our industrialists a little more every day.
I want to prove this with the climate package that was signed under the French presidency.
I want to prove this with national initiatives, such as the carbon tax, which Mr. Parniaud just mentioned, and I welcome it, which pushes for the establishment of ecological taxation.

A sector like transportation, which is among the major CO2 emitters, even though some modes of transport, such as aviation, emit less greenhouse gases, is increasingly contributing to the fight against climate change.
However, this is a sector that has suffered a very strong counter-impact from the crisis.

If, as I wish, maritime and air transport are integrated into the negotiations in Copenhagen, then let us make sure that what is asked of European industries is also asked of those of other industrialized countries.
In Copenhagen, the world's public opinion will have a laugh and will be clear and diligent. Please finish, please. Do not disappoint us. Thank you.
Madam President, dear colleagues, the Copenhagen summit is a historic opportunity to change the course of the planet.
We must reach decisions that are even more binding than those made in Kyoto.
We must also call on our leaders to create an international organization such as the WTO, which is responsible for regulating climate change and environmental issues, to create a fund
adaptation to climate change, in addition to, of course, public development aid, to create a carbon tax, maritime and air, as we must also do on financial transactions.
We can see the urgent need for global environmental regulation, such as financial markets and the Internet.
We have the opportunity to open this margin of history through the environment
Let us do it in the image of our highest human aspirations, otherwise we will appear as responsible people without any control over the reality of things. Thank you.

Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, my dear colleagues, less than two weeks after the Copenhagen conference, concerns about the success of the climate change negotiations are growing.
Some, by the way, already say that it will be a failure.
Major world powers are still reluctant to show all the ambition that the climate emergency imposes on us.

By adopting the motion for a resolution tomorrow on the European Union's strategy before the Copenhagen conference, we, the European parliamentarians, must show that our determination is first and foremost total and that the conference must lead to an agreement, certainly precise, but above all binding.
Moreover, the binding nature of this agreement that will be reached must not be questioned.

We cannot indefinitely postpone the decision-making to tomorrow, otherwise it will be too late, hence the necessary creation of a global environmental organization, which today appears not only necessary but also urgent, since it will be led, under the auspices of the UN, to control the application of the commitments made in Copenhagen
We must, from Copenhagen, be able to expect more lucidity and responsibility from this world.
Mr. President, I would like to support the joint initiative of the British socialist government and the French government to return Afghans in an illegal situation to their territory.
Indeed, contrary to what some people have said, these people had their political asylum application rejected. This bilateral initiative must now be extended at the European level.
Migration pressure is a challenge that we must face collectively, and this is the meaning of the pact on immigration and asylum adopted a few months ago under the French presidency.
We must now go further by pooling our resources and organizing joint return flights funded by Frontex.

The decision of the twenty-seven to ask the Commission for a study on this subject is a first step, and Commissioner, I hope that the Commission will support this proposal, because the fight against illegal immigration is an expectation of public opinion and, in particular, of the immigrant populations in a regular situation.
Mr. President, I would like to return to a recent event, the Swiss vote on minarets.
Certainly, this vote took place in a non-EU member state, but it is obvious that it touches on a question that is not foreign to us.
I would like to return to this event because I also see it as an excuse to talk about secularism, and we never talk too much about secularism in this chamber.
It is necessary and urgent that the principle of secularism dominates the organization of our society, and I would like to say simple things here.
First of all, the opposite principle of secularism is not religiosity, and even less spirituality.
The principle, contrary to secularism, is religious communitarianism, which enacts rules and laws that are superior to civil laws, and communitarianism that locks individuals in infrasocietal groups.
Our Union, by its history, is multicultural and multi-ethnic.
It is and will be more and more so, and only secularism can allow individuals.
Mr. President, the CESAR program, which aims to modernize air traffic management in Europe, is a major project.

How will the Commission prepare the next phase of redeploying Csar, and in particular the financing of this program, which is essential for the environment as well as for our scientific and technical impact?
Will the Commission follow the recommendations of the report submitted in 2007, according to which a high-level qualified personality should ensure the political follow-up of this program?
Indeed, it will require overcoming many legal, psychological and technical obstacles by unifying national airspace and making the controllers of the different countries work together.
If Europe was not able to unify its sky, how would it be able to build a strong political unit?
Mr. President, Minister, dear colleagues, the importance of the issue of climate change is no longer proven.
These short, medium or long-term impacts are undeniable, even if today the results of the GESC in a certain national newspaper are on the front page and certainly reinforce the positions of skeptics.
The Copenhagen summit appeared to the world as a unique opportunity for world leaders to testify, act and correct the effects of this process, which is climate change.

The European Union was at the forefront of this platform, not only thanks to our bold legislation on limiting the impact of our activities on the climate, but also because Europe represents a union of countries that can really make a difference.
Of course, the outcome of the Copenhagen conference can only leave a taste of dissatisfaction, but I refuse to speak of failure.
The world has agreed on the issue of limiting the temperature increase by two degrees, even for a most reluctant country like China.
Brazil has just enacted a law aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions by nearly thirty-nine percent by 2020, in line with its commitments.
However, many others have also shown great ambitions regarding the objectives of reducing greenhouse gas emissions.
I am thinking of Japan and Norway.
Moreover, it is also necessary to emphasize the very positive point that was the consensus reached regarding the urgency of a mechanism for reducing emissions due to deforestation.
A specific and unanimous text was obtained on the implementation of the direct mechanism to reduce deforestation and thus allow the natural storage of CO2.
Far from a binding agreement, but clearly in line with a political agreement, the outcome of Copenhagen must lead us to question the reasons for such disappointment.
I went to the Copenhagen conference, like many of my colleagues, with the desire to participate, to help and to see a negotiating Europe, a leading Europe, act.
My disappointment was great because Europe clearly did not have the place it deserved in the negotiations, especially when it comes to the European Parliament.
To assert itself, Europe must show itself stronger on the subject.
The meeting of our environment ministers in Seville did not lead to anything, and our leaders were uncertain, hesitant, and we remain divided on our objectives.
I hope that Mrs. Edegarde, strong in her proposals and commitments made before the Environment Committee, will be able to update the ambitions of the European Union.

Thank you. I give the floor to Mr. Baudis. Dear colleagues, to avoid caricatures, we have heard a few this morning, I would like to recall some objective elements concerning Tunisia, a partner country of the European Union.

The social situation has evolved very favorably, with a spectacular increase in the average per capita income, and now the vast majority of Tunisians meet the criteria defining membership in the middle class.

More than ninety percent of Tunisians benefit from social coverage, and more than a quarter of Tunisia's budget is dedicated to education, so this country is among the first to have achieved the Millennium Goals in terms of primary education.
Finally, as Mr. Michel recalled earlier, women's rights are recognized and guaranteed.
At university, there are more female students than male students, forty percent of professors are women, a quarter of the deputies, local elected officials or journalists are women.
Many countries could envy such results.
Mr. President, the acts of fanatical criminals who killed Christians in Egypt cannot be attributed to an entire people and their government.
It would be unfair to hold Egypt and the Egyptians responsible for this abominable massacre, whose perpetrators will be judged.
Let us not confuse the actions of a criminal with the policy of a country, let us not make a confusion between fanatics and an entire population. Finally, by claiming to stand up for
Between the Coptic Christians of Egypt and their Muslim compatriots, we give arguments to extremists who seek to present the Christians of the East as agents of the West.
Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what is happening in Greece, Portugal, tomorrow in Spain or Ireland is scandalous.

These same Anglo-Saxon agencies, which complacently rated the issuers and merchants of toxic assets and saw nothing coming, are today of the utmost severity towards the states that have stepped to the rescue of a financial sector that did not deserve it.

The crisis caused by the irresponsibility of the markets and banks, and this massive aid are directly at the origin of the worsening of deficits and public debt that these same markets claim to sanction today.
This is the moralization of capitalism proclaimed by Mr. Sarkozy, the European Union and the G20.

All the bankers have learned from the crisis is that the taxpayer is an inexhaustible source of resources, profits and insurance, because there is a rumor that the extent of this panic comes from a large American bank that has benefited from government aid.

American and two hedge funds of the same nationality that want to profit from both the exorbitant interest rates imposed on Greece and the CDS market, these government bond insurance policies that are themselves the subject of independent speculation.
It will not be enough to regulate hedge funds, which you are afraid to do, or derivatives markets, as Mr. Barnier proposes.
There is no need to create a European economic government.
The twenty-seven are in the same difficulty anyway, and solidarity is not an option.
It is the global free movement of capital that must be called into question, otherwise there will be no
Mr. President, there are still less than fifteen of the bluefin tuna stock today.
Faced with such numbers, the solution seemed obvious.
However, we must not forget the jobs affected by the decisions that concern us today.
It should be remembered that CITES is not intended to ban fishing, but only the international trade of this fish, which is exported to Japan for eighty percent.

By safeguarding tuna, we are certainly protecting a dangerously caught species, but we are also encouraging the maintenance of a more balanced, more sustainable fishing activity, a fishing destined for our domestic market and that generates jobs.

I am in favour of the idea of including bluefin tuna in Annex I of CITES and although it seems to me that this decision will be positive, the Commission's help to allow for a thorough restructuring of the fishing sector
My question is therefore about the modalities of this support.
France is asking for a 18-month suspension, accompanied by financial measures for sailors and shipowners affected by a ban on trade.
What is the Commission's vision on the subject?
Moreover, my concern, like many of my colleagues, is about fairness.
How can we guarantee that boats flying the flags of countries such as Tunisia, Libya or others will apply the ban on international trade with a rigor comparable to ours?
What will be the new control and sanction measures?

The sustainability policy of our economic activities must be concrete, sometimes even unpopular in certain sectors, but I hope that the Commission and the Council do not lose sight of the necessary adjustments to the implementation of these measures.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, as the rapporteur has reported, this proposal for a directive is indeed a follow-up to a vote by the Parliament, as you also recalled, Mr. Commissioner.
However, my group remains extremely critical of this proposal because it risks turning against those we want to support.
By wanting to lighten the burden on companies, we risk depriving them of the conditions of transparency and trust that are essential to their management and the dynamism of their activity.
First of all, I believe we need to be clear about the thresholds and what is called micro-entities.
This concerns SMEs with more than ten employees and more than one million euros in turnover.
Regardless of the member state, it represents a very large majority of companies.
Of course, they may be local and not very present on the Community market, but the need to present accounting rules will not be abolished for them.
Accounting rules, they will have to face them whenever they want to deal with a banking organization, with partners or sometimes negotiate with tax, economic and social institutions.
At that point, accounting rules will be imposed on them and they may have to pay more than for regular accounting in order to meet criteria that they do not necessarily know.
I do not see any progress in imposing the accounting obligation outside of any common framework in the European Union.
This is not just a competition issue, it is simply a matter of economic integration and community law, and equal treatment for all European Union companies.
That being said, of course, simplifying accounting obligations for SMEs is a necessity.
Three initiatives, by the way, go in this direction, whether it is the proposal we are talking about today or the international IFRS reference framework.
I am interested in the revision of the fourth and seventh accounting directives, for which the European Commission should soon make proposals to us.
These proposals were promised to us for 2010, it seems that they will be extended, but I do not believe that this extension of the deadline is a sufficient reason for this
to rush and do half the work, because these three proposals, if they share the same objective, may not have the same articulation. It seems to me that it would be better, Commissioner,

and clearer for businesses, to provide them with a single and comprehensive response that will allow them to reconcile the objective of simplifying the obligations desired by all and the reality of life of small businesses that need it.
The current problem is that the European Commission is dragging its feet in proposing a revision of these directives, and this is detrimental to our thinking.
I therefore call on the European Commission to speed up the dialogue on the issue of exemption, which today divides both European institutions and economic circles, and to conduct an impact study.
