Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner and my dear colleagues, as my colleague Elisabeth Morin Chartier and the other colleagues have pointed out, on February 27 and 28, the violent storm Cynthia hit several French regions, causing 53 victims and enormous material damage.
The storm was of rare intensity and caused devastating floods on the French coast.
After Madeira, Europe is once again concerned.
Brittany, the region of my colleague and friend Alain Cadet, has been severely affected.
Three French departments have been declared in a state of natural disaster: Brittany, Poitou Charente and the Loire.
Faced with these disasters, the European Union must show its responsiveness and express its solidarity.
It is not only with words and resolutions, but also and above all with financial aid that we can support the victims of these disasters.
I therefore invite my colleague Christophe Bchut to join my approach and the European Commission to quickly unblock the Union's solidarity fund to help the affected regions cope with the damage.
This disaster demonstrates the relevance of Michel Barnier's proposal to create a European civil intervention force.

Europeans must act together because disasters are multiplying and affecting our European territories, and in particular our most isolated and vulnerable regions, such as the islands in the Indian Ocean and the Caribbean.

Madam President, I would also like to congratulate our rapporteur Jrg Leichtfried on his text and his spirit of cooperation on this file, and I support in particular his proposals on the financing of air safety, since we are talking about air safety here and not about air security.

For many years, our committee has been fighting to get the principle accepted that stricter safety measures must be the responsibility of the member states, and I fully support our rapporteur on this point.
Indeed, security is not just about travelers, but about all citizens, and it is the responsibility of the States to take measures to fight terrorism.
It is therefore not justified that air passengers bear the sole burden of financing safety measures at airports and on board planes.
This is all the more true because in modes of transport such as rail and maritime, states finance, depending on the case, partially or totally, safety measures.
I therefore think that we must remain firm in the face of the Council and defend to the end the thirty-second amendment of the report adopted by our transport committee.
So I had another point to address quickly.

Although I support the progress made in non-discrimination and transparency that the text will bring, I do not believe that the purpose of this directive is to establish a single and identical European system of safety fees.
While requiring compliance with common rules, member states must be allowed to maintain their current system of collecting fees.

Thus, in states such as Spain, Italy or France, the fees are voted by the Parliament and, in this case, it must be the authority that appeals against the laws that must act as an independent supervisory authority.
And this is the subject of amendment forty, which I hope many of you will support when we vote on it.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, the report I am presenting to Parliament tries to explain that agriculture has a place and a role to play in the fight against global warming.
Nature reminds us this week that volcanoes in particular can have a major impact on human activities and the climate.
But this still requires that men, and Europe in particular, take their responsibilities to fight against what is called global warming.
My report tries to show that agriculture can both continue to reduce its carbon emissions, reduce its fossil energy consumption and, above all,
On the other hand, it has participated very actively in carbon fixation to fight globally for less carbon emissions and more carbon fixed and sequestered.
This report tries to show that in agriculture, we should move from a compartmentalized approach, which consists of opening a directive every time we have a problem.
on soils, on water, on pesticides, I don't know, and trying to address the agricultural issue with the ambition to deal with it in a global, systemic way.

In this approach, we must be able to find ways to ensure that agriculture, as I said earlier, not only reduces its energy consumption, but at the same time participates very actively in carbon sequestration.
This is particularly the role related to photosynthesis, biomass, and, above all, what is dear to me, also related to the soil, to this ability that European soils have to fix organic carbon.

I think that this path, which I open in this report and which I hope will be followed during the vote that will take place in plenary in Brussels, must allow European agriculture to enter a phase of sustainability, to ensure a

An ecological transition to this agriculture that would put it ahead of a number of other continents or other agricultures to ensure that it is capable of being economically efficient, ecologically efficient and, from that moment on, socially efficient.

This report deals with a particular issue, the fight against global warming and agriculture, but it claims, at least I hope so, to open up other perspectives to fuel, in particular, the debate that will take place on the future of agricultural policy after 2013.
I am addressing the Commission, I will address and I have often done so in the agricultural committees, I will also address the various ministers when I have the opportunity.
I think we need to take a turn.
The CAP of 2013 must be ambitious.
It must be based on objectives that allow citizens to understand why we need a common agricultural policy.
We need a common agricultural policy because the Europe of agriculture must ensure both food security and also commit to the path of sustainability.
This is, in any case, what I propose in this report, and it is on this that I hope that the Parliament, by a large majority, will follow me.

Mr. President, I would first like to emphasize that the precautionary principle implemented by most European governments by closing their airspace in a targeted and provisional manner was a wise and prudent decision.

The safety of our fellow citizens must take precedence over any other consideration, and under these conditions, the attitude of some airlines, which demand the total and immediate reopening of airspace on the basis of one or two test flights, seems at the very least indecent.
I believe it was Mr. Hennin who spoke earlier about the complementarity of modes of transport, particularly with the train, and I will take the opportunity to say how much I regret the air paralysis
This has been accentuated in some countries, such as France, by the disorganization of rail transport due to strikes in these circumstances, which are irresponsible and incomprehensible.
Returning to our topic, I would like to welcome the Commission's decision to authorize the granting of public aid to airlines affected by the ongoing disruptions.
This is a sensible decision in a context already marked by the crisis, but these aids must be exceptional.

In this regard, I would like to see among the criteria chosen for granting them the exemplary performance of the companies in the compensation allocated to their clients who have been victims of cancellations of flights.
Indeed, it is not acceptable that some companies abuse the force majeure clause in order to escape their obligation to compensate passengers under Regulation 261/2004.
Travellers are victims of the current situation and if no alternative solution is proposed to them, they should not bear the financial cost.
In addition, travel agencies are exempt from the obligation to reimburse travelers for unused flights.
This is not normal either.

Companies, like travel agencies, have insurance that covers them in exceptional cases, like the one we have been experiencing for a few days, and it is therefore necessary to ensure that travelers are well compensated for flights that have been cancelled.
Mr. President, chaos, paralysis, cacophony, disaster, disaster, words are not lacking in the press to mention the closure of European airspace and its consequences.
I will not dwell on what has already been said, particularly with regard to the extent of the colossal, abyssal financial impact, one might say, of this crisis in direct or indirect terms.

Although I am pleased with the possibility of considering the granting of exceptional public aid to the airline sector, which has already been strongly approved since September 11, 2001, I remain equally perplexed about the European management of events.

One, knowing that seven hundred and fifty European passengers have been injured, of which a good part is still stuck in all corners of the world, knowing that economic losses are exponential with the passing of time, how can we explain that it took a
It is not one, two, three or four, but five days for European transport ministers to meet by teleconference to coordinate their actions and decide on the creation of differentiated traffic zones.
Two, no one disputes the need to apply the precautionary principle as an absolute priority, but today, as traffic in areas is gradually reauthorized
Secure, unchanged weather, and while the volcano is still active, we are entitled to wonder what additional safety guarantees we could have provided earlier and more quickly for passengers.

Three, an evolutionary action model has been developed, the evolution according to the weather and the volcanic activity can change from hour to hour, which will continue to carry out the updated assessment of the security of the corridors
Do these test flights have to be carried out by civil aviation and airlines?

Finally, if this continues, worsens or repeats itself, which is likely, the management model in place will have to provide for greater coordination of the Member States and special operational procedures based on real data,

coordination of other means of transport in exceptional circumstances, but also taking into account the necessary coordination of the repatriation aid of tens of thousands of blocked passengers who also have the right to information and assistance.
However, so far, only isolated and national initiatives have been taken.
Madam President, I would like to express my thanks to our colleague Mendes de Vigo, who has done remarkable work in sometimes passionate and always passionate conditions, after other speakers.
The debates within the Constitutional Affairs Committee have lasted a long time. They have been up to the challenge and the intensity of the interest that the.

European parliamentarians on the major issue that concerns them first and foremost, quite legitimately, the composition of our Assembly and the modalities of appointment of the members of our Assembly.
Once again, the rapporteur was able to bring together opinions and contributions that were sometimes different and synthesize, I would say, in an extremely balanced text, opinions and views.
I wanted to thank him for that.

I believe that the recommendations of these two reports, both the one concerning the convening of the IGC and the one concerning the transitional measures for the composition of our Assembly, are marked by realism, pragmatism and effectiveness.
This is what, overall, and on other subjects as well, fellow citizens expect from Europe.
Mr. President, Mr. Dalli, Mr. Commissioner, it is with great force that this draft report, as presented just now by Mr. Peterle, takes up the lines
The European Commission's communication is a guideline and is also inspired by the European Parliament's resolution of April 10, 2008 on the fight against cancer in our European Union.

Let me support the objectives of the European partnership envisaged by the European Commission to fight cancer more effectively, whether it is the importance of preventing early screening, developing a new model for cancer prevention and, above all, reducing inequalities within the Member States.
I share the concerns and worries expressed in the European Commission's communication and the draft report.
I would like to commend the work done by Mr. Peterli, the rapporteur, in the context of drafting this report and the compromise proposals proposed to take up the various amendments.

As shadow rapporteur for the Socialist and Democrat Group, I wanted to emphasize the following issues, first of all, the increase in annual deaths related to cancer caused by exposure to carcinogenic agents in the workplace, but also the importance of better access to

information on medicines for cancer patients, but also the implementation of the REACH regulation and the regular update of very worrying substances that include carcinogenic substances, support for initiatives aimed at preventing the importation of goods

containing carcinogenic chemicals, and to strengthen the control of the presence of chemicals within the European Union, and finally, the development of guidelines for a common definition of disability that can include people suffering from chronic diseases or cancer.
These are the questions we wanted to ask while supporting this draft report.
Madam President, the escape of oil drilling in the Gulf of Mexico is a real ecological and economic disaster.
It appears that irregularities were found in the granting of forest permits by the US Treasury.
This would be an unforgivable carelessness, whose consequences are incalculable and do not only concern the United States of America.

When you know that hundreds of offshore drilling permits are granted by states around the world, if these permits are granted with the same lightness, it would pose a real, serious problem for the whole world.
elected from the outermost European regions and the OCTs, entirely composed of islands, almost entirely of islands, nearly one hundred and thirty.
In total, spread over the three continents, I must express my great concern for our islands regarding offshore oil exploitation projects.
This is why it is imperative that the European Union, having to set an example, reviews with the utmost rigor the safety and prevention measures on its own offshore oil platforms.
Moreover, accidental or operational oil spills at sea, not necessarily due to Europe, are estimated at several tens of thousands of tons every year.

Wouldn't it be appropriate for the European Union to take initiatives so that offshore platforms are now under the control of an uncontested international scientific authority, which should be set up in the form of an international authority?
After Copenhagen and in preparation for Cancun, the European Union would be honored to initiate a real global governance for the research, protection and exploitation of marine resources.

In continuation of the Barcelona process, the Union for the Mediterranean is an opportunity for the development of our relations with the countries of the East and the South of the Mediterranean basin.
As Vincent Payon's excellent report points out, we cannot neglect the potential of this region or the dangers it carries.
However, having the lucidity to admit it, since the bombing of Gaza and with the continuation of the colonization of Palestinian territories, the Union for the Mediterranean is at an impasse.
The political aspect is blocked.
We are not even sure that the summit scheduled for next June in Barcelona will take place.
I would not be surprised if we learn in the coming hours or days that it is an unprecedented day.
We must not give up, but the European Union must take more responsibility in the search for a political solution.
We cannot leave the United States the monopoly of political management of the crisis in this region, which is ours, by simply contributing to its development.
The development and stability of the Mediterranean condition our security and our growth, and for this reason, the Union for the Mediterranean remains the best instrument at our disposal.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, this is an extremely important issue concerning consumer protection.
A recent survey indicates that the food safety situation has deteriorated in the eyes of Europeans over the past ten years, and one in three consumers remains suspicious of the quality of products.
Therefore, updating, simplifying and clarifying food labeling in the European Union is an obligation for better consumer protection.
Let me address two points.
Regarding the color code, we are in favor of this color code if it is accompanied by a reference to nutritional values expressed in percentages.
I am opposed to a mandatory nutritional declaration for wines and spirits.
We want a specific regulation for wines and spirits to be drawn up in the next three years instead of the five years proposed by the European Commission.
This is what I wanted to point out, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner.
Madam President, High Representative, this attack on civilian ships by the Israeli commando obviously requires an impartial and credible investigation.
But what credit could we give to a Commission that would be both judge and party?
This attack occurred in international waters, so it concerns the international community, and it particularly interests Europe, bordering the Mediterranean.
Europe should make itself heard more and be more involved in the search for a political solution based on two states, each with Jerusalem as its capital.

Europe is making considerable financial efforts to contribute to the development of the Palestinian territories, but unfortunately, it is too absent from the political process that should lead to the creation of this Palestinian state.
The financial and budgetary goodwill we show is not enough.
We must also express a political will and take the means to make ourselves heard.
The brutal killing of Mavi Marmara by the Israeli army evokes emotion and condemnation.
emotion in front of the nine victims of the assault of civilians, condemnation because this arrest in international waters constitutes a violation of international law.
In doing so, the Israeli government penalizes its people, because in the end, we see, with the strengthening of extremes, the ultimate goal of security in the region moving a little further away.
Yes, more than ever, the Israeli government must renounce the policy of force.
However, I would like to point out that the strong media coverage of the Mavi Marmara flotilla, orchestrated from Turkey, casts doubt on the exclusively humanitarian purpose of this operation.
An investigation seems essential to shed light on the assault, but also on the preparations that preceded this expedition.
And I hope that the Israeli government will accept that this investigation includes substantial international participation to finally find the paths of justice in this region.
Madam President, High Representative, I welcome the new dynamics induced by the launch of the Partnership for Modernization and its pragmatism.
This new partnership, if it were only for that, would at least have the merit of highlighting how essential a geopolitical partner Russia is for the European Union.
I also welcome the positive comments on cooperation with Russia in crisis management.
However, a few remarks.

While the Union's demands are always highlighted, the interests or positions of its partner seem to be systematically underestimated or disregarded, whether it is in the field of energy or in the way it can analyze the Eastern Partnership and the Atlantic aspirations of its closest neighbors.
I also notice that the firmness shown by most member states and the Union in their speeches, the virulence of condemnations of human rights violations, seems to be reserved for Russia alone.

The words are more polite, the diplomacy more featured, as if it were about China, for example, these systematic violations of the rule of law, if only about the Laogai, this global factory in view of the European minimum social requirements, when our French or European workers are unemployed.

Let me remind you of the Adagio d'Angusta, father Augusta: to the summits by the narrow paths, because that is how I consider the efforts of today's Russia, delivered from the Marxist criminal poison that, for so many decades, has bleeded and locked this country up.
The current Russian Federation will have been able to take over the leadership of an entire nation despite the difficulties and major challenges that remain to it.

So, a little modesty, gentlemen Europeanists, especially when the European superstate, on the other hand, does not achieve any of its beautiful goals, despite increasingly expensive means and the gradual domination of the states of Western and Central and Eastern Europe.
I also cannot help but recall that this Assembly had more indulgence towards the communist Soviet Union than towards Russia.

Moreover, it is often the same people who yesterday advocated for the unilateral disarmament of the West and for participation in Mr. Gorbachev's House of Commons who today experience the most virtuous indignation and the greatest modesty towards the Union-Russia partnership.

On this subject, I must inform you, if you are not yet aware, of new historical facts that will emerge due to the gradual translation of the Soviet secret archives that a brave Mr. Pavel Stroilov will have been able to obtain archives that have already given and will give many more.

Unpleasant surprise to the classic of the unique thought about the reality of the end of the Cold War, which was really Mr. Gorbachev, and the packaging of today's pro-European powers, who then enthusiastically wanted to make some Soviet projects possible.
At the risk of repeating myself, Russia is an essential and strategic partner for European states and our relations must be strengthened for the benefit of all parties.
This country is much closer to us in terms of culture, civilization, history, geography, mutual interest or common risk than some states that you are preparing to join the European Union.
The Presidents of the Council have often said that necessity makes law.
Faced with the crisis, it is obvious that there is an inevitable necessity to innovate and be creative.

In this regard, I welcome the step taken by the Council, a step that I hope will eventually be a giant step leading us towards true economic governance, because let us not be mistaken, the simple coordination of economic policies will remain insufficient.
Can we achieve a true budgetary federation, not forced by circumstances, but because we would have decided it ourselves?
Let's go back to the Council's decisions, which I am still pleased about.
Strengthening the preventive aspect of the Stability and Growth Pact is a great thing, but there is no real budgetary discipline without sanctions for those who deviate from it.
They have been strengthened but not yet specified, which is a regret.

Otherwise, I would like to express my satisfaction, among other things, with the guidelines decided, such as the famous competitiveness scoreboard, because that is what it is all about: to regain competitiveness and sustainable growth for all.
Let us also welcome the project to establish a bank tax, the acceptance of a financial transaction tax, and the acceleration of the reform of financial regulations.
Mr. President of the Council, all these decisions and guidelines seemed, a few months or even weeks ago, unrealistic, illusory, or even hypothetical.
You are right, it is true, it is a profound change in culture at the scale of the policy of small European steps.
That said, it is now mandatory that in October, the States implement these guidelines very concretely.

It will now depend on the Council whether the step taken is a historic giant step or simply a pious wish, which we will all have to regret bitterly and, in particular, a majority of citizens, to endure on a daily basis. Thank you.

Mr. President, we have already discussed this at the Conference of Presidents. Many groups are divided on this Gallo report and, apparently, the Parliament and all groups still need to discuss because there are contradictory points that the groups have not been able to resolve.
That is why we are asking to postpone the debate and vote on the Gallo report, that is, to September, September 2, when we will have to see the Conference of Presidents.
So it's a very simple thing.
Since the fruit is not ripe, let it ripen in the summer and discuss in September.
Madam President, I must admit that I have trouble following my colleagues who love to show their muscles and claim the monopoly of our legitimacy in the face of the other institutions of the Union.
Unfortunately, their attitude is often derisory.
But when the members of this house, with hard work and conviction, affirm an argumentative position, when
We defend what resembles a European general interest in the face of tense states, the situation changes completely.
In this debate on European supervision, the Parliament played this role.
Regarding the European Systemic Risk Board, for which I am the shadow rapporteur of my group, I, like the rapporteur, Mrs Goulard, defended an ambitious line.
I advocated mechanisms that ensure a certain degree of effectiveness and I insisted on the preeminence of the European Central Bank.
Why?
Because the European Central Bank is indeed the only community institution in this whole and because it has shown its seriousness.
For Christian charity, I will keep silent about the names of all the institutions and all those great figures who suddenly disappeared during the storm
We can be happy to have had at least one captain on board at the height of the crisis.
I will therefore be reassured to see tomorrow macroprudential supervision backed by a strong community institution, while microprudential supervision will inevitably remain fragmented.
In these troubled times, the European Systemic Risk Board must get to work as soon as possible.
The future will show whether adjustments will be necessary, but it is essential to start on a healthy basis, because systemic risks affect the entire European and global banking sector.
Mr. President, the final agreement on the revision of the directives on industrial emissions is more than acceptable, and I welcome the compromise work that has been done.

This final package takes up the key points of the position that I defended with several of my colleagues within the environment committee, which aimed to make this text ambitious but realistic legislation.
Firstly, maintaining a certain flexibility for companies and competent authorities in granting exemptions.
I would also like to welcome the new version of the ESN, which is so controversial and which, now limited to certain sectors, seems much more feasible.

It is also important to emphasize that the agreement reached allows for better articulation with the ETS directive and definitively removes from the text of the new directive the irrelevant idea of creating a CO2 and NOx quota market.
However, there are a few caveats not to be forgotten, and more particularly the provisions relating to the soil.
As the soil directive is still pending, this important issue will unfortunately only be addressed by the Member States that have their own legislation.
Tomorrow, the Parliament must adopt the elements of the agreement reached at the end of the trilogues.

A huge amount of work has been done from all sides to avoid the referral of this text to conciliation, a text that, I must remind you, is of crucial importance both for the industry and for European environmental policy.
Madam President, every day brings its share of information that shows us the extent of the ecological disaster caused in the Gulf of Mexico with the breakdown of the offshore platform.
But let's not forget that other disasters of this kind are happening elsewhere.
I am thinking in particular of what is happening today and for a long time already in Nigeria.

That is why, in addition to the moratorium on new drilling, I think there is a need to promote stricter rules regarding the management of platforms, not only European rules but also international rules.
As for the European Union, I think it is necessary that it provides itself in a preventive manner to fight against this disaster and I think it is obvious
also that all this argues, as Mrs. Damanaky said, for a firm and resolute choice in favor of clean and renewable energies,
And the European Union should set an example in this matter.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, reopening negotiations with Mercosur while the European Union is about to redefine its agricultural policy reveals a dangerous lack of coherence on the part of the Commission.
Europe already imports five hundred tons of beef.
A new opening of our market would be at the expense of European disadvantaged breeders, without guarantee of respect for health and social standards.
We cannot accept this.
Europe buys thirty-eight million tons of soy and livestock.
These imports from Brazil and Argentina monopolize more than nineteen million hectares.
They are concentrated in the hands of three companies: Cargill, ADM, Bunch.
Between 2001 and 2004, soybeans destroyed more than one point two million hectares of tropical and equatorial forests.
This is one of the main causes of the increase in greenhouse gas emissions and the disappearance of biodiversity.
The European Parliament has decided to produce a report on the reconquest of autonomy in plant proteins for livestock feed.
Environmentally friendly agriculture and the fight against climate change dictate this choice.
These efforts will be in vain by this draft bilateral agreement.
Once again, the European Commission is selling its agriculture and its peasants to obtain random compensation for service companies.
These concessions will not serve the peasant families of Mercosur, but the interests of agro-industrial groups.
To be convinced, just read the report of the Tyson group, an American company, a heavyweight of the international meat market,
who announces that he has invested in Brazil to, I quote, and this is in his report, use this country as an export platform for Europe.
Other companies, such as the Doux company, had already anticipated this approach by buying back the Brazilian group Frango Soul in 1998.
Many poultry farmers, particularly in Brittany, had paid the price for this operation.
Europe seems to want to continue its relocation policy by amplifying its attacks.
against the peasants. We must stop
Mr. President, many colleagues are concerned about the consequences for European agriculture that the reopening of negotiations on an association agreement with Mercosur could have.
My group and I share these concerns.

It is indeed to be feared, and as a member of parliament for an ultra-peripheral region, I have experience with banana agreements. It is therefore to be feared that an agreement with Mercosur will bring a difficult blow to many European agricultural sectors.
This is why an impact study is absolutely necessary.
It is also to be feared that this agreement will turn Mercosur's agriculture a bit too much towards productivist agriculture, at the expense of small farms that exist in these countries.
A balance must therefore be found so that this agreement does not transform the Latin American and European continents into superpowers, essentially rooted in the dogma of mercantilism.
Mr. President, I would simply like to tell you that we may not have done our agenda well today.
If we allow free trade agreements to enter European territory, products that do not respect our social nor environmental standards, the CAP reform will be useless.
Very clearly, we cannot remain in a hypocrisy where, on the one hand, we impose environmental, health and safety traceability constraints,
to our farmers on the grounds that consumers must be protected and, on the other hand, to allow products that can enter our continent freely without respecting these
The question that is being asked behind the negotiation with Mercosur is indeed this.

And the way things were initiated, whatever we are told about the fact that Parliament was very well informed and that things happened in the greatest transparency and clarity, does not lead us to give a positive assessment of a negotiation that is taking place while negotiations are continuing at the WTO in parallel.
In the name of consistency, consumer protection and the protection of our farmers, I do not believe that we should continue in this direction.
Madam President, I would also like to commend the work done by the rapporteur Jos Bov, the Commissioner and the intervention of Mr Dess, who preceded me, on the objectives of this report.

I think it is very important to keep in mind that in the debate we are having, we have to solve a problem related to price volatility in agriculture and especially related to the fact that when prices
They increase, they are very quickly passed on to the distribution level, but when prices fall at the production level, there is no repercussion among consumers.
There is indeed a problem with the organization of the sector, there is indeed a problem with the distribution of what is called added value within the sector.
I think that Jos Bov's report offers perspectives on several points that must be highlighted and here I am really addressing the Commission to try to get out of this fundamentally negative spiral.
The first, of course, is the organization of the sector and the balance of power within the sector.
What proposals do we make so that producers gathered and organized have more weight in the sector to negotiate?
This is the question you raised, Commissioner, of inter-professional relations, but it is also a question of the contractual basis that will be put in place.
I argue, and this is in the report, that this contractual basis should have a European framework.
We cannot let each country solve this problem.
There must be a European framework.
It must be flexible, but it must exist.
This is a proposal, an inseparable path for me.
Secondly, of course, the issue of price transparency.
And on this, I am in favor of setting up this observatory, which is absolutely necessary so that we can inform consumers of price evolution.
So, I support the proposals that are made and I hope, as Mr. Dess said, that there will be a majority to follow.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, today I would like to welcome this debate, which marks once again the need for the Union to appreciate and value its regional diversity.
During these negotiations for the new framework programmes 2014, it seems important to me to highlight the adjustments that specific regions must benefit from.
The issues of continuity and territorial cohesion must be at the center of our concerns.
But the development of mountainous, island or sparsely populated territories requires more than a set of derogatory measures.
We need a horizontal approach.
We must put in place instruments capable of making all areas of Community action coexist in synergy in order to strengthen their added value.

Moreover, as a representative of the outermost regions, I am eagerly awaiting the new strategy of the Union for the Outermost Regions, which the Commission services have promised us for the beginning of 2011.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, first of all, I agree with my colleague's position on the Council's absence from this Parliament meeting.
I find this a bit of a discount from the Council, I also want to say that.
As the next summit on October 6 approaches, China and the European Union must absolutely and resolutely try to move forward together on the issue of climate change.
Last year, at the same time, we were already busy in this very chamber urging Europe to do everything to achieve an ambitious and binding agreement in Copenhagen.
We saw that the result did not live up to our hopes and ambitions.
So, the concerns a year later are the same, or even much more vivid.

So, in order for us to be able to force or convince our partners today, we must show that our determination is absolutely intact, show, for example, that we are giving ourselves the means to honor our commitments to the countries of the South.
For this, the implementation of innovative financing, and I heard President Sarkozy's speech at the UN yesterday, becomes a necessary obvious fact.
For example, the introduction of a carbon tax at our borders is not to be ruled out.

It would act as an incentive mechanism for countries that do not go far enough in their commitment to the climate and much more than a threat, ultimately, and a way to protect our jobs and our businesses, especially to better address the post-crisis period.

Madam President, I do not agree with the need to revalue family leave. Raising the minimum threshold for maternity leave is a step forward, a benefit, and we must not be totally demagogic when comparing the economic impact with the qualitative benefits that are difficult to quantify.

But the problem is essentially of two orders: one, the economic context, it is true, but not enough to leave millions of families on the verge of starvation for decades, two, the legal gaps in the report, because the text contains several types of family leave whose legal bases are not reconcilable.
Let's take the adoption leave, which is in the text under the same title as maternity and paternity leave.
Personally, as an adoptive mother and for all those I embody, I appreciate the desire to give equivalent rights to those of biological mothers.
I am, in fact, the small additional package that Mrs. Morin was talking about to add to the Estrella report.

If the goal is indeed to strengthen the health and rights of women, of all women in the labor market, adoptive women, who have become mothers in the same way as others, have the same rights and the same protection at work.
These are full-fledged mothers, who adopt a child older than twelve months, and please do not discriminate, as stated in the text.
As for the adoption, I regret that the text was so inadequate.
It was not even supported by the Rambol impact study.
All of this is not well done, which is clearly a weak point.

Nevertheless, despite these caveats, I will support Mrs. Estrella's report, because beyond economic considerations, there are men and women who must not only better assume their parenthood in a society of

More and more resigned towards the education of these young people, but also because it is our duty to ensure that no one has to choose between sacrificing their children for their work or sacrificing their work for their children.
Finally, we are not sitting in the Council but in Parliament. If we, directly elected officials, are not ambitious, tell me who will be.
Madam President, Commissioner, Mr. President of the Council, I would like to intervene and not go back over the debate as it has taken place so far.
We discussed a budget for 2011 with the constraints we know, that is, the deep crisis that Europe is going through, with public deficits at the national level, which can lead to two hypotheses
These public deficits at the national level constrain the European deficit, or these national deficits must give a new direction and a new breath at the European level.
That is the question.
I ask you, Commissioner, to try to think, when discussing a budget review, when we start talking about budgetary perspectives for the post-2013 period, not to
to remain totally imbued with the context of the crisis, except to tell me and all the citizens of Europe that, definitely, Europe will remain in the crisis for a long time.
Our whole problem is indeed to manage the crisis and reduce our deficits and debt, but it is also to prepare for the exit from the crisis.
And that is where the budgetary question arises.

We will only be able to get out of the crisis, and Joseph Dole said this right away, if the European budget, because it is European, is able to give us the means to find what we lack today: growth, job creation, innovation, research.

That is the issue, and it is at this age that we must discuss the budget, and not, as we do all too often, constantly integrate the issue of the crisis, the issue of deficits, and the Council is excellent.

I noted that in Deauville, Angela Merkel and Nicolas Sarkozy even announced in advance a reform of the treaties without even having discussed anything with Mr. von Rompuy to sanction all the states that would not respect budgetary discipline tomorrow.

This is where we are at the Council level today, whereas Parliament is asking for only one thing, and in particular to the Commission, to try to pull the European project, and this is done through the budget.
So you have noted a number of things on which we completely agree.
More flexibility is needed.
Obviously, we need to find together the ability to have a much more flexible budget, because it is necessities and the reactivity of Europe that is at stake.
It is also, of course, a matter of setting priorities and organizing the effectiveness of the European budget.
We will all agree on this, we all agree, it is a necessity.
But where we need to be clear among ourselves is that we need to have a timetable, we need to set goals together, Commissioner. It can't just remain words, commitments,

These are texts that are very interesting and which I share almost one hundred percent. But now, we will have to get down to business, and in particular on an essential issue around which we are turning: own resources.
How can we have our own resources tomorrow for Europe, not for Europe, but for all European citizens, and to find together the path of growth and an even stronger path for Europe tomorrow?
It is up to you, Commissioner.
Mr. President, I would like to focus my speech on the preparation of the next G20 summits.

Everything has been said by previous speakers about European economic governance, about the need to strengthen European economic governance, to strengthen the Stability and Growth Pact and to better involve the European Parliament and, of course, the national parliaments in the process.
I would like to quickly mention two challenges that our nations and the members of the G20 face and which, in my opinion, must be addressed in the context of the next G20 meetings.
the challenge of the currency war and the volatility of commodity prices.
I think that on these two subjects, which are real threats to global growth and cause very significant imbalances on our planet, the European Union must.

The European Union is able to organize itself, to establish common positions, to give itself the means to speak with one voice at the next G20 summits in Seoul, but also those that will follow, and more broadly on the world stage. Thank you.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, I would first like to congratulate our colleague Diogo Fejo on the quality of the report and the ambitious proposal it contains.
This also shows that the European Parliament is taking its full place in a debate that is decisive for the future of Europe, and we can only be pleased about that.
Moreover, the Greek crisis has been a revealing of the malfunctions that undermine the economic governance of the European Union.
I take note of Mr. Feyot's proposal to establish a permanent mechanism for financial stability on this point.
We also need to address the problem at its roots.
For this, I think the solution also lies in strengthening the Stability and Growth Pact, and in particular sanctions.
This is essential if we want a sustainable consolidation of the budgetary situation of the States, which is not always popular.
It is binding, but we have no choice.

Mr. President, I believe that the report clearly shows the stakes that the marine environment represents in terms of fishing, aquaculture, transport, tourism, energy, mineral and biological wealth, and research combined with climate change.
This is a considerable development potential that should be secured, protected and sustainably highlighted, because the future of humanity depends on it.
The report also rightly notes that the European Union is the world's leading maritime power and that its outermost regions offer it the world's largest exclusive economic zone.
In view of such a finding, it is therefore up to the European Union to implement an ambitious policy, a major sea policy.
If it is not the world's leading maritime power that does it, who will do it in its place?
But it is clear that the resolution does not go very far in this direction.
It is not with fifty million euros that one can claim to occupy the leading position in world politics.
Finally, while the outermost regions have a recognized strategic position, since they are present in all oceans, it would have been
It was wise to give them a major role in a major ocean strategy, which unfortunately was not retained by the report, and I regret it. Thank you, Mr. President.
Madam Commissioner, I would like to return to the anti-counterfeiting agreement that is currently being negotiated, particularly with the United States.
This agreement also raises questions in the United States, particularly among the officials of the US Patent Office.
Moreover, seventy-five American law professors have just sent a letter to President Obama.
They believe that ACTA, a simple executive agreement, would be contrary to the American constitution.
As you know, the European Parliament is about to adopt a resolution on the ACTA agreement, which still raises great concerns and is far from being unanimous.
I think it would be useful for our American interlocutors to give us a very clear answer on two points: Can ACTA be ratified by the United States?
Is ACTA, in their eyes, a binding or voluntary agreement?
Indeed, an anti-counterfeiting agreement, which China, India and Brazil are already absent from, and which would not be implemented by the United States, would greatly lose its credibility.
Thank you.

Mr. President, throughout this difficult birth of the alternative funds directive, I have constantly advocated for the principle of equal treatment between fund managers, whether they are from the European Union or not.
This principle sounds obvious, but it has been met with countless difficulties.
The result presented to us today is satisfactory in nature.
I thank the negotiators and especially our rapporteur, Mr. Gauzs, who, after this birth, which was particularly painful for him, would deserve substantial maternity leave.
However, I would like to emphasize that the issue of the treatment of third countries must still be observed in two ways, whether we are inside or outside the European Union.
Thanks to the European Parliament, in particular, all funds sold in the European Union will be subject to comparable regulations.
We can therefore more or less speak of a level playing field.

It remains that, during the transitional period, non-EU entities will benefit from the national investment regime, while European Union funds and managers will be subject to the directive, which is generally stricter.
The situation is different on markets outside the European Union. There, European funds and their managers will remain subject to the directive, which is not the case for third-country funds.
It would therefore be much more difficult to sell European products in the rest of the world, as they would be less flexible and more expensive.
We must be aware of this disadvantage, even if it was inevitable for the time being.

As for the depositaries, let us also know that we will make the exercise more binding, particularly because of the new responsibilities that will fall to them. The increase should lead to substantial changes in the profession.

Mr. President, I am not saying this to show my opposition, but to indicate that this new regulation is not trivial, its necessary implementation will also involve difficulties that we must be aware of.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, especially at the beginning of the 21st century, patients need appropriate information in order to be fully involved in the care process, to know where to seek care, to decide on the best treatment in agreement with health professionals and to follow the planned treatment to the letter.
Today, patients are demanding independent, comparative and adapted information to the needs of each individual.
Unfortunately, the proposals for the revision of the directive transmitted by the European Commission did not adequately meet the needs expressed by European citizens.
These proposals opened the door to direct promotion by pharmaceutical companies, which seems nonsense to us in terms of responding to the real needs of patients.
This operation is of no interest to either citizens or member states.
Unlike additional bureaucracy, it means an increase in expenses and making patients take risks.
It was for these reasons that we initially presented a proposal to reject these texts, thus asking the Commission to review its copy.

This approach, also adopted by my colleague Carl Schlitter from the Green group, allowed our rapporteur, Mr. Fechner, whom I salute, to proceed with an important revision of the Commission's proposals.

At the same time, we had tabled about sixty amendments aimed at better protecting the health of our citizens and facilitating patients'access to independent, comparative and adapted information for the needs of each individual.

The adoption of these amendments in the Environment Committee has allowed for greater emphasis to be placed on patients'rights to information rather than making the provision of information an option for pharmaceutical industries.
In light of the compromise amendments obtained, we decided to withdraw our proposal to reject the texts, the substance of the text having evolved in a good direction over the past few months.
The amended draft report has managed to counterbalance the European Commission's initial proposals.

However, we continue to refuse that health professionals can be used to distribute brochures and information provided by pharmaceutical companies to their patients without any control by health authorities.
Similarly, we will oppose the authorization of industrial information campaigns, particularly in the field of vaccination.
Information cannot come freely from pharmaceutical companies.

Experience shows that we must be very vigilant and, in conclusion, what happened with Mediator drugs shows how vigilant we must be and ensure that this balance point, as we have sought with this draft report,
Mr. President, Commissioner, Minister, unity and realism will be achieved, at least I hope so, when tomorrow we vote on our resolution on this sixteenth Conference of the Parties on Climate Change.

I hope that our Commissioner in charge will be able to carry out the pragmatic objectives that we will have to achieve collectively, but also to defend the sine qua non conditions set by Europe, which are associated with it.
In these negotiations, we must not lose sight of the legitimate expectations of fairness of our fellow citizens and our industries.
It is the world that must fight climate change, not Europe alone.
Therefore, recognizing the importance of too little protected intellectual property will be essential.
Green technologies must benefit the greatest number, but we must not sell off our present and future knowledge, even for this indispensable fight against climate change.

Similarly, asking for common methods of calculating emissions, as well as verifying and publishing data so that all emitting industries are subject to the same scale, seems to be a legitimate request and not a bargaining chip.
Finally, more controversial, and my colleague raised it earlier, the shortcomings of the current system of clean development mechanisms will also be put on the table.
Dear colleagues, we are all well aware, with regret, that the European Parliament does not have the real negotiating power.

But the will of many European deputies, of whom I am a member, to work and participate in a positive outcome of this conference must be encouraged and not neglected, as we have been able to feel in recent days.
If Europe wants to be strong in international dialogues, it must be the same for all its lawmakers.
Madam President, the European Union often presents economic partnership agreements as an opportunity for African countries.
So, is she desperate not to see these agreements signed as soon as possible?
But the question that challenges us is why these countries are not in a hurry to sign agreements that would be so favorable to them.
Obviously, the assessments of the quality of these agreements differ, and as long as these differences in assessment persist, the ACP countries will hesitate to sign them.
Wouldn't it be appropriate to go further in dialogue and understanding by listening to the concerns and expectations of the ACP countries?
They want to talk about development strategies, while Europe often responds only by opening up markets.
This is the listening that the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly requires.
I think that other European institutions should proceed in the same way if we want to build a real strategic partnership between Africa and the European Union.
Christians are undoubtedly one of the most persecuted religious groups in the world.

In the Middle East, they are perceived by some extremist groups as legitimate targets, and their goal is their simple departure from this region, a region that has seen the birth of Christianity, and in which their historical presence is necessary for a certain balance.
The events of the Cathedral of Baghdad are only the culmination of a situation that we have been passively observing for far too long.
The European Union, as a global player and trade partner of many countries in this region, must express its strong indignation in view of the situation.
Discrimination, whatever it may be, cannot be tolerated.
Democracy will only be victorious in this region when the most fundamental human rights, such as religious freedom, are respected.
Dear colleagues, we are all concerned about the serious crisis that currently prevails in Cte d'Ivoire.

It is clear that the decision of the country's constitutional council to question, in violation of the electoral code, the results of the elections officially proclaimed by the Independent Electoral Commission is unanimously condemned by the international community.

The European Union, the UN, the African Union, the European Union-ACP Joint Parliamentary Assembly, the COAS and, certainly soon, the European Parliament, are calling for the respect of the official proclamation of
election results and the installation of the new president of the republic, as recognized by the Independent Electoral Commission, which, I recall, is a body validated by the UN.
All the political groups in the European Parliament have expressed their agreement on these essential points in a joint declaration.

They also called for any escalation of tensions in the country that could lead to a civil war, which would be a human, social and economic disaster for Cte d'Ivoire, which must obviously be avoided at all costs.
Madam President, I would like to thank our four rapporteurs, who have done remarkable work and have added significant value to the European Parliament's text initially proposed by the Commission.
The citizens'initiative that we, the EPP, are preparing to vote enthusiastically is a major step forward in the Lisbon Treaty.
Let us not be mistaken, this instrument can truly change the European political landscape, provided that it is used with both responsibility and audacity, I repeat responsibility and audacity.
It can contribute to bringing European citizens directly into the European political debate.
It can contribute to the emergence of a European public opinion, that is, men and women, citizens of Europe, who debate together, take positions together and come together on truly European subjects.
But let us not disappoint our fellow citizens.
Let us urge our member states to take implementation measures quickly where necessary. Let us not disappoint our fellow citizens, it is about strengthening European democracy.
Mr. President, I, in turn, like several of our colleagues, would like to address the issue of the persecution of Christians all over the world, particularly Christians in the East.
There is no need to recall the horrific acts recently committed.
I would like to solemnly recall that defending Christians in the East, as everywhere in the world, advocating for religious freedom, and the diversity of

Belief is advocating for freedom, democracy and human rights, which are values at the heart of the European project and which, of course, are universal values, at least we are all convinced of them here.
It is really time now, beyond indignation, emotion, solemn condemnations, of course, to move from words to actions.
I urgently call on the authorities of the European Union, the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, but also all our governments, the foreign ministers,
To commit to precise measures, to implement a precise, concrete action plan to make respect for religious diversity and the fight against all forms of religious persecution a priority. Thank you.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, High Representative, we all agree that the situation in the Sahel region has deteriorated considerably.
And allowing a no-fly zone to settle in European ports is a danger that we must fight firmly and without delay.
Extremist groups are multiplying and threatening the lives of civilian populations.
In my turn, I deplore the loss of human life and the hostage-taking and I am concerned about the European nationals on the ground.
Until now, Morocco was a bulwark against all kinds of trafficking from the Sahel.
Now, drug, arms or human traffickers are bypassing Morocco, passing through Mauritania to the Canary Islands, towards the European Union.
It seems to me that it is the responsibility of the European Union to act to help its states put an end to these threats.
Europe's security is at stake on our territory, but also in its immediate vicinity.
It is time for us to act and I ask the Commission and the Council to implement an action plan to help return to security in the Sahel.
This has been said, but I join the signs of sympathy and support that have already been expressed towards the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples.
It represents a symbol of hope for all defenders of freedom.
A thought also for the victims.

I would now like to say that the European Union, which, as has been said, has been noticed for its lack of reaction, must stand by the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples to help them carry out the opening of their country to reforms and to establish democracy.

The European Union has decided to support the Tunisian leaders in engaging in a peaceful transition, to prepare the organization of the upcoming elections to gain freedom and allow the Tunisian people to find prosperity, development and social peace, an economy that will allow young people to find employment.

I would say, to conclude, that the Union for the Mediterranean has a major challenge to overcome because the jasmine revolution has triggered a wave in all the states of the Maghreb, the Middle East and the Middle East.
It must implement a strong strategy towards these countries.

But be careful, in the face of this legitimate democratic movement, Europe must find a balance between non-interference in internal affairs, support for the legitimate aspirations of the people and stability.
Commissioner, my colleagues have reminded me of this many times.

At a time when Europe is wondering about a common strategy for its supply of raw materials, and particularly of rare earths, we cannot neglect the immense potential that the intelligent valuation of our waste represents.

Strengthening European standards to improve the functioning of collection channels, addressing the problems of leakage or illegal export of dies, or increasing our collection targets must be at the heart of this legislation.
Let us not forget the main player in the success or failure of this regulation, the consumer.
Citizen accountability is crucial if we want to implement effective legislation.
And to do this, my dear Karl Heinz, eco-contribution, among other systems, has proven to be one of the most relevant tools.
Producers of electrical and electronic equipment must obviously be more involved in the collection and recycling system, but the citizen cannot be discouraged from the waste he produces.
Our citizens must be actors, not spectators, of European environmental policy.

Madam President, Commissioner, I would first like to share the remark that Mrs. McGuinness has just made about the fact that there is an essential link between the food issue and the agricultural issue.
The subject that concerns us is the increase in food prices, with the consequences that this can have for a number of populations in the world, but also in Europe.
First, I would like to try to share a finding.

The trend of increasing agricultural prices and agricultural raw materials is a long-standing trend for me, and it will last for three essential reasons: the demographic evolution of the world and the increase

of the world's population. Second element, the fact that we have entered, with global warming, into climatic uncertainties that pose a problem, whether it is drought or floods. And the third point, because the world is also developing,
With new emerging countries, consumption levels are increasing.
So, tension in agricultural markets and agricultural raw materials is a major trend.
It is exacerbated by price volatility, and price volatility is a consequence of the financialization of the global economy.
And it is this subject that we must also address if we want to resolve both the agricultural and food issues.

And to do this, what the Commissioner said is important: there are two elements: yes, there must be transparency on stocks, but there must also be a public stock policy in Europe and stock management on a global scale, particularly at the UN level.

Second point, regulation of financial markets and financial speculation is needed, particularly by refusing that speculative volume no longer has any connection with the physical quantities that are traded on the markets.

We cannot accept that speculators come to speculate on the food issue without taking into account the consequences that this can have, since it is about the food of the world and of humanity. I conclude by saying
And that brings me to two major consequences: we need a strong European policy and we reaffirm strategically Europe's commitment to being a global food and agricultural player.
Secondly, we need to change our development policy to ensure that, on a global scale, and Europe is a player, we invest again in agriculture, because we will need all agriculture to feed the world.
Madam President, Commissioner, as in two thousand and eight, the price of agricultural raw materials is rising on the world markets.
We are only at three percent of the level of 2008.
The decline in production in some traditional exporting areas due to climate change, the diversion of cereals through the production of agrofuels and speculation
The financial markets that have had an increase are responsible for this situation, as shown by the reports of the IMF, the French authorities and the Commission.
The consequences of this new food crisis are hitting hard the one and a half billion inhabitants in the world who live below one and a half dollars.
Since October, forty-four million more people have joined those who live below the poverty line.
Two days before the G20 meeting, what is Europe waiting for to take measures similar to those voted in the United States?
Since January 13, 2011, the US administration has been demanding the limitation and transparency of positions taken by financial funds on agricultural commodity markets.
This step is the first step to counteract the appetites of speculators.
The impact is also dramatic for European farmers.
They are no longer able to feed their animals.
Hundreds of farms are bankrupt.
Five years ago, wheat was worth one hundred euros per ton, today it is negotiated at nearly three hundred euros.
The situation has therefore completely changed.
The Commission demands that farmers adapt to market signals, and it would be well advised today to follow its own advice.
Faced with this crisis, the European Union cannot wait until 2014 to find solutions.
We must face the crisis and I propose three concrete actions.
Firstly, the creation of stocks in the countries of cereals to be made available to breeders at subsidized prices immediately.
Secondly, the indexation of meat prices paid to farmers on the evolution of the price of livestock.
Thirdly, for 2011, a mechanism for transferring a part of the aid intended to support cereals to animal production. Thank you.
Mr. President, are we ready in Europe to face a pandemic?
The answer is yes, but there is a but.
The H1N1 flu episode in 2009 showed us that each member state reacted on its own, without much coherence or even solidarity.

As a shadow rapporteur on this file, I think we should have made these observations, but above all, we should have gone further, been constructive and concrete for our citizens who, it must be said, and this is what seems most damaging to me, have probably lost some confidence in public health messages.

Mrs Rivasi's report, which will be voted on tomorrow, takes into account these fundamental priorities, which are, among others, the systematic strengthening of cooperation between Member States, better coordination with the
European health institutions, clarification of the roles of European health risk management structures, evaluation of vaccination strategies and communication implemented in the Member States.
This is a good report, and I congratulate the rapporteur. Of course, it must not remain a dead letter.
It is the responsibility of our member states, which retain the main competences in this matter, and therefore it is a real responsibility to be taken towards our citizens.
Mr. President, it is my turn to express my very strong emotion after the cowardly assassination on March 2nd of the Pakistani minister in charge of Christian minorities, Mr. Bhattie.
This terrorist assassination follows many other assassinations of brave, tolerant, human rights lovers, human rights defenders and women's rights activists, I must say.
Once again, we urge the Pakistani government to shed light on this cowardly assassination and to effectively ensure the protection of people threatened by fanatical religious extremists.
Of course, I think first and foremost, but not only, of Mrs. Sherry Raymond.
I also wanted to strongly ask all the competent institutions of the European Union to include in the negotiations for
To prepare future cooperation agreements, including the cooperation agreement between the EU and Pakistan, a clause on respect for religious freedom and human rights. Thank you.
Mr. President, as a reminder, with the crisis and the explosion of the real estate and credit bubble, the Irish state had to intervene to support the banks.

The Irish public deficit and the cumulative budget balance of central, local and particularly social security administrations were estimated at thirty-two percent of the gross domestic product in 2010.

If the Irish government, which can hardly refinance itself with the markets, wishes to access loans from the European Financial Stability Mechanism and the Fund, it will have to meet social and fiscal change obligations, while these areas fall under subsidiarity.
In our opinion, this is not antinomial.
As a doctor, I would say that in the case of fever, it is no use prescribing antipyretics blindly without trying to address the cause.
In the case of allocating these funds, it is up to the state to clean up its finances in order to fill its excessive deficit and correct its previous mistakes.
This austerity plan should improve the GDP by ten over the next four years.

Just as a private individual, a bank, without interfering in his private life and management, will condition his personal loan to a solvency guarantee, just as the European Union can lend to Ireland on the basis of a consolidated solvency.
Without interfering with its private management, the bank will encourage the individual to negotiate, for example, a salary increase or to borrow elsewhere.

Thus, while respecting subsidiarity, the European Union, on the basis of a memorandum established with the IMF, considers that this solvency involves a reduction in the legal minimum wage and an adjustment of pensions without exempting itself from tax measures.
It is up to Ireland to choose whether or not to implement these measures.

It is not the door open to European Union interference in the areas of subsidiarity that would allow, for example, the dangerous imposition of a minimum European wage level, but rather the protection of the stability of the euro area through a mutual guarantee process.

Of course, we should help Ireland like other countries in difficulty, which also protects us, but not at any cost, especially the cost of seeing a state unable to repay in the long term, thus weakening its citizens and those of the entire European Union.

Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, the eruption of the Icelandic volcano last April, and many of us said so just now, has provided a painful illustration of the fragmentation and inefficiency of the European sky.
and each of us in this hemicycle has been directly concerned.
And five million of our fellow citizens found themselves stuck without a real alternative transportation solution.
One year after this exceptional event, new European measures are still pending.

As you said, Commissioner, a first crisis exercise related to volcanic ash is planned for the next thirteen and fourteen of April, under the coordination of Eurocontrol, ICAO and IATA, but it is essential that the AESA assumes real leadership for the coordination of safety measures at the European level.
It is certain that the information provided by the London and Toulouse vaccines must be refined using more modern technological means.
These data, as seen last April, can, however, be contradictory and can lead each member state to make decisions regarding the closure of its airspace, less motivated by information than by emotion.
In this context, the role of the AESA is essential to propose a harmonized interpretation of these data, as well as to ensure the centralization and proper dissemination of information.
Beyond the information provided by the ECA, the AESA must set up a mechanism for collecting available data by closely involving member states, airlines and their pilots.
This centralization of information and the coordination of all the actors concerned will avoid the chaos and inconsistencies we witnessed last year.
I therefore expect the Commission to be able, together with the EASA, to quickly present concrete proposals that will be fully integrated into the implementation of the Single European Sky.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, this text is important.
It is not a revolution, we cannot say that everything was going wrong before and that everything is perfect now.
However, it presents a number of major advances at this provisional stage of our work.
The main ones, in my opinion, concern better regulation of distance sales, particularly on the Internet, and that is chapter three, because consumer rights need to be strengthened in this area.
E-commerce is very useful, it broadens the consumer's choice, allows him to get the lowest prices, and also allows small and medium-sized enterprises and craftsmen to find new outlets.
To make progress in this area, it was necessary to do so in a truly European way, that is, on a few very targeted points, to establish a complete harmonization of the rights and duties of each.
To be very concrete, an Italian customer who buys on a Belgian or German site should know that they will now benefit from the same rights and protection.
This is what this directive will make possible.
This means that its withdrawal period will be extended to fourteen days throughout the Union.
This means that he will know the total amount he will have to pay right away, without fear of a bad surprise afterwards.
This means that with the double click, it will correctly check its order.
Obviously, all this will shake some habits.
In many states, there are subtleties in national law that everyone is convinced are fundamental, while sometimes they are not even found in neighboring countries.
But living together in Europe means learning to change our habits a bit in the service of the community and general interest.
Let's be clear, this text will still need to be improved and we will have to do it in the coming weeks with the Council and the Commission.
I appreciated the openings that have just been made in this regard.
But we have already done substantial work thanks to our rapporteur Andrea Schwab, whom I warmly thank.
But the real fruit of this work is above all the fact that the amendments will be voted on tomorrow by all the political groups.
Consumer confidence in the Union's internal market is very fragile.
This political unanimity was needed to preserve it and hope to strengthen it.
In point seven, after the first paragraph, a first draft, guarantee respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, in particular
freedom of speech and assembly, the right to demonstrate peacefully, and to listen to and take into account the legitimate demands of the demonstrators and to ensure their safety.
Madam President, dear colleagues, Commissioner, the open sky agreement between Europe and the United States is a step forward, but it is only a step that puts Europe in a dilemma.
The Transport Committee and the Commission themselves have emphasized this.
Either we accept an agreement that disadvantages European companies, or we suspend the agreement and risk losing the profits made since 2008.
Let me draw a parallel with the licenses of private and professional pilots, a text that will be discussed before the summer, because the pilots I am a part of are faced with a dilemma.
The European Aviation Safety Agency, wishing to harmonize licenses on European territory, will do so at the expense of eighty to ninety general aviation pilots
directly concerned, some of which hold only one American license, and at the expense of, and this is important, companies and jobs related to this activity.
I would like to draw your attention to this project, which has no security basis.
There are thirty-one times fewer accidents among American license holders.

The objectives of the basic regulation text two hundred and sixteen allow for the recognition and equivalence of licenses, which are not in the interest of waiting for hypothetical agreements postponed to two thousand fourteen.
So, I propose a very open sky agreement and even invite you to accompany me when I sometimes come to Parliament to fly myself, to demonstrate that an American piloting license is entirely safe.
Madam President, at this stage of our debate, I will inevitably have to repeat or support some of the things that have been said before.
But I also wanted to say, like several of my colleagues, that the problems that the entire European Union is currently facing cannot be solved by any single member state.
No member state should be alone in the face of the challenges that arise for it and, once again, in my opinion, for the entire European Union.
So it is really the ability of the European Union to organize itself and to face in a common, solidary way, that I call for.
I believe that the time has really come now to lay the foundations for a genuine European immigration and asylum policy.
More than a year ago, a European asylum and immigration pact was adopted.
I think the time has come to put it into practice.
So, we listened to the Commissioner, we heard a number of recommendations she made.
I wanted to come back to it and strongly support some of these proposals.
Yes, the resources of the Frontex agency must be strengthened at all costs.
Therefore, we need to strengthen the human, material and financial resources of the Frontex agency, allow it to provide more support for the Hermes and Poseidon operations.
Yes, additional financial resources are needed for the member states that are, I would say, the first to face the increased migratory flows we are experiencing today.
and it will be the financial expression of our solidarity.
Yes, we need to establish closer cooperation relations with the states on the southern shore of the Mediterranean, of course, support them, help them, and find instruments
The Commissioner mentioned, I believe she went to Tunisia to talk about mobility partnerships.
Yes, these instruments must be strengthened in a spirit of responsibility, in a spirit of solidarity, but also in a precise and concrete spirit.

Mr. Commissioner, you are probably aware that the most heated discussions we have had here around your communication concern the place of public services, services of general interest in the single market and their legislative translation.
We have reached a compromise formulation that invites you to go beyond your twenty-five proposal and we ask you to go beyond a simple
communication that would not meet the expectations and needs of the actors, users and all stakeholders in public services, nor would it meet the objectives that you also formulate.
The European Union must send a clear and unambiguous message about public services.
To achieve this, we must create a positive legal framework, a regulation or a directive.
The Treaty of Lisbon gives us the legal basis.
It is up to you to translate them into legislative proposals now.
I think the Parliament is ready to follow you in this direction.
First of all, congratulations to all the rapporteurs for their gigantic work on this discharge and I also welcome the Council's presence in this debate.
The seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg is a matter of European identity and it is not just an economic issue.

I am discussing this today in this hemicycle, on the occasion of the debate on the discharge for 2009, because the symbol of Franco German reconciliation is treated by some members of the Budgetary Control Committee as a simple way to make savings.
The issue of Parliament's expenses also interests me.
In this regard, I suggest we hold group weeks in Strasbourg rather than in Brussels, as this would allow us to make our Parliament's seat in Strasbourg more profitable.
Since we want to save money, I propose other things, for example, to remove the Friday's loss of our colleagues, as well as the removal of the loss of journalists.
Europe is attractive enough that we are not forced to give a lost tenure to journalists.

Let us not hide behind the budgetary argument to appropriate an important issue that goes beyond the framework of budgetary control, although I welcome the important work of Villeux, our rapporteur, regarding this discharge.
Finally, since we are talking about the economy, I also want to see the compensation system for sponsored visitor groups moralized and cleaned up.

I don't think it's very moral and it gives a very bad image of our institution that the group manager is reimbursed in cash on the day of the visit without any work, any control of what the group has spent.
