Sometimes, the allocated amount, I would like to point out, exceeds the amount of actual expenses.

It would be logical for the groups to send a quote to the visiting service in advance, to receive a discount from the Parliament on expenses, and that on a bank account, and that the balance is paid on the presentation of the invoices actually paid, with a ceiling, of course, thank you.
Madam President, I am addressing the Commission and my colleagues, and I welcome the presence of the Council.
The question that arises today emerges from the management of the Schengen area in 2011.

This is no longer the space of the five member states of the 1980s, but rather a space that has continued to expand in recent years and now includes twenty-five states, three of which are not members of the European Union.
Like all European policies, Schengen cooperation must therefore adapt to the reality it covers today, which is no longer the same as it was ten years ago.

It is in this sense that we must read the proposals of the Italian and French governments and the pragmatic and necessary responses provided today by the Commission in its communication on immigration.
Mutual trust between the Schengen area member states is certainly the cornerstone of Schengen cooperation.
But this trust is based on mutual obligations.
If one of the parties does not respect its obligations and creates air calls, the whole system becomes failing.
It must therefore be possible for other states to respond to this failure by re-establishing temporary and strictly regulated control of their borders.
In doing so, these failing states will clearly be invited to better control their external borders.

Moreover, as presented by the Commission, these measures would fully respect the spirit of Schengen, insofar as these controls would be reintroduced as a last resort and the decision would be taken at the European level and not at the intergovernmental level.
Such measures will be intrinsically linked to all long-term measures in the perspective of a common migration policy.
It is notably essential to strengthen Frontex, to provide more solidarity to support the states located at the external borders.
The situation in the Mediterranean in recent years only highlights a shortcoming of the Schengen acquis.
Madam President, in a few weeks, migrants from the Mediterranean coastal countries have represented a significant percentage of French annual immigration.
This achievement is not static, but must evolve instead.
I hope that this proposal will be adopted quickly, ensuring better management of our Schengen area and, in doing so, ensuring the security of our common external borders. Thank you.
Mr. President, the European Union has finally taken sanctions against Syria.
But unfortunately, she seems to do so with a trembling hand, carefully avoiding questioning the head of the Syrian regime.
This lack of determination and clarity is obviously interpreted by the protesters as a form of abandonment and by the government as an indulgence that allows it to intensify
repression, a repression so cruel that one cannot imagine for a moment that at the same time Syria could be elected to sit on the Human Rights Council of the Organization of the
United Nations, while today the Syrian authorities refuse UN observers access to the city of Dera, the scene of terrible violence against defenseless civilians.

Syria in the Human Rights Council would be an insult to the victims and their families, an encouragement for this regime to use brutal force against its people, precisely in contempt of the values of which the Human Rights Council must be the guardian.
So, High Representative, what diplomatic options do you consider to avoid such a disaster?
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to congratulate my colleague Carlos Coelho, who has done a great job on this report, and God knows that it was very complicated.
Bulgaria and Romania have made considerable efforts to strengthen their border control and have succeeded.
Whether it is police and judicial cooperation, data protection, visa policy and air, sea or land border control, the latest assessments are very clear.
All technical criteria are met.
We can only note this state of affairs.
Bulgaria and Romania are now able to implement this Schengen acquis in technical and personnel terms.
Moreover, if no obstacle today prevents this expansion of the Schengen area, we note that a number of recommendations have been addressed to these two countries.

I hope that these recommendations will be strictly monitored, particularly with regard to the borders between Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey, because, as you know, mutual trust between the Schengen states is based on the full respect by these states of their mutual obligations.
If one of the parties does not respect its obligations and creates air calls, the whole system becomes flawed.
I very much hope that an agreement will be reached in the Council in order to welcome these two countries into the privileged circle that the Schengen States form.
And we all measure in this chamber the scope of this type of decision for the citizens concerned.
Congratulations again to Mr. Coelho for his report. Thank you, Mr. President.
In its Europe 2020 strategy, the European Union has set itself the goal of making our economy greener and our transport more modern.
All European institutions have largely supported this objective, including almost all member states and our Parliament.
In this context, it is therefore regrettable that since 2008, several Member States have worked to empty the new proposal for the Eurovignette Directive of its content and blocked this file.

Today, however, thanks to the tenacity of our rapporteur and I would like to greet Sad El Khadraoui here, thanks to his tenacity and that of the shadow rapporteurs in their negotiations with the Council, we finally have a compromise before us.

This text is certainly much less ambitious than the initial proposal, but it will allow for the first time to put into practice the polluter pays principle and to internalize external transport costs such as noise or CO2 emissions.

In order for this Eurovignette not to be a simple tax but to contribute effectively to the improvement of transport in Europe, the Member States are also encouraged to reinvest the money collected in the modernization of transport modes.
The Parliament also managed to obtain concrete inventions in terms of interoperability of toll systems, as well as stronger incentives for the use of less polluting heavy goods vehicles.

In order to remain consistent with the political objectives set by our institution, I sincerely hope that we will be able to adopt this compromise proposed to us at second reading and thus pave the way for a more sustainable transport policy. Thank you.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, yes, I agree that with freedom and fraternity, there should be equality with peasants and countries that have returned with Eastern countries.
Yes, I agree with you.
I believe we have taken a big step forward with this report.
It wasn't easy at the beginning and we were in a confrontation, but we reached a consensus and that is the most important thing.
This consensus allows us to protect the overall project, and I believe that this is the great merit of the European Parliament.
We succeeded in this betting and it was not easy, so I thank the rapporteur Murciudes and all the parliamentarians.
First step.
In this text, we reaffirm the need for both equality, justice and fairness between producers and between territories, and I believe this is important.
We have said very clearly and confirmed the maintenance and development of small farms, the consideration of small farms, which are essential for the quality and biodiversity of the territories.
I think that was also fundamental.
The fact that we introduced the notion of making agriculture agronomic, of turning the page of industrial productivist agriculture, is written in the texts.
This will now have to be implemented. It is a condition for making agriculture possible for future generations.
It is not an ideological question.
Finally, today, the concern we have is that there are indeed threats to the budget.
This will have to be answered clearly.

Now, what we are waiting for is for us to actually enter the second phase, which is clearly the legislative debate, because beyond the texts, the great intentions, it is in the legislative debate that we will really see where we are going, and that is what we are obviously waiting for now.
I would like to end by shouting out in anger against Germany's attitude, which has led to a five-fold reduction in food aid to the poorest in Europe.
It was in the CAP budget.
I want us to find a way to help the poorest. There are eighty million European citizens who do not eat properly when they are hungry.
Mr. President, as much as the European Parliament can boast of some great advances in economic governance, I invite my colleagues to show humility, because we are dancing at the end of the abyss.
Let us be well aware of two things.
The first is that the European Parliament has remained inaudible in the Greek crisis.
While we are usually so quick to react to all sorts of events with a resolution all over the world, this existential crisis seems to leave us speechless.
I deeply regret that we were unable to send a strong, concrete, simple message to the Greeks, to the governments of the member states, to the European citizens.
The second observation is related to the scope of this package.
By voting on what I want these six directives and regulations, we will certainly take a step forward for the Eurozone.
Moreover, towards a discipline that we have so desperately missed, a step, I say, nothing more that will show its usefulness in the future.
But we only need to see the discussions about the reversed qualified majority ignited to measure the path we still have to travel, when it should be about automatic rules and sanctions.
The mechanism of qualified majority by reverse majority continues to act on some as a horror.
However, we must remain firm on this principle.
On a strictly political level, I regret that the left-wing benches continue to reject the principles of good budgetary management, against all obviousness.
Yes, deficit and sustainable growth are antinomial.
Yes, states must also manage their budgets as a good family father, but not through public spending. It is a soft poison in the short term, but it is never a sustainable solution.
As the coming weeks are crucial, today it is a matter of re-founding an economic union.
This morning, after three years of work, we voted on a very important text for the progress of consumer protection in Europe.
It rightly focuses on online shopping, which may in twenty years represent twenty-five percent of all trade in Europe, which is quite considerable.
These purchases will be cross-border in particular.
They will allow consumers to have a wider choice and also pay much less.
This is real progress.
For SMEs, for all craftsmen, this is also a very important opportunity to expand their outlets.

Among the main advances, I would like to mention just two: the withdrawal period, which is increased to fourteen days, and the summary of all the information and the overall price to be paid before pressing the last button that passes the order.

And finally, I am proud, in the context of these explanations of vote, to say that I and all our colleagues voted unanimously among the political groups, because on such a subject, we did not need controversy, but obviously consensus.
If we have achieved it.

Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to start by congratulating our colleague Carlos Coelho on this very difficult file, which required a great deal of technicality, a lot of work and knowledge of the file.
The control of our common territory and our European borders is one of the most important issues we must face, and the technological tool is more than ever at the service of this challenge.
Indeed, in the past few years, we have witnessed an unprecedented development of European databases and the exchange of personal data.
What some call a digital tsunami should certainly be confirmed in the coming years.
SIS, VIS, Eurodac are all essential instruments today to ensure the security of our European citizens.
Ensuring good operational management of these databases is therefore a major issue to which it is our responsibility to provide an effective response.

This response is of course very delicate and Carlos Coelho had to face many legal, institutional, budgetary, political and technical obstacles, and yet he managed to reach a balanced text that satisfies all the interested parties.
The creation of this network agency seems to be the best solution to ensure the internal security of the member states.
No other existing institution or agency could take charge of the proper management of these information systems today.
It will improve the management of existing information systems, offer better synergy between these databases and also allow the integration of instruments that will be adopted in the future.
One of the very delicate questions that arose in this case was the Agency's headquarters. Where should it be established?
Estonia and France are the only two countries that have applied to welcome it.
France has already hosted the Schengen Information System in Strasbourg, which it has been managing and administering since 1995, and therefore has total technical control over it.
Following the conclusions of the European Council of December 2003, which gave priority to the new member states, Estonia also wanted to receive the seat of this future agency.

It seems to me that the compromise found is very good. A sort of distribution of missions, I conclude, Madam President, was carried out by transferring the Agency's headquarters to Tallinn, where the tasks of governance, strategy and program design will be carried out.
The development and operation of the systems will take place in Strasbourg
The cost-effectiveness report is very balanced and this compromise solution in no way calls into question the centralized management of IT systems.
Mr. President, the transversal social clause and Article 14 of the Treaty of Lisbon guarantee social rights in a binding manner, including the right to access services of general interest.
It is time to prove to European citizens that social Europe is on the move.

We must therefore give our social achievements all the place they deserve in Community law, recognizing the specificity of the SSIG in terms of competition rules, knowing that these services have a strong local anchor and rely on social economy actors.

Mr. De Rosa's report is an opportunity to affirm the simple but strong principles of equality, universality, and access to these services organized collectively, which are factors of well-being and social progress.
Madam Commissioner, you said it is time to put it into practice.
Yes, it is time to move on to the concrete. I propose that in this debate, there really be a European legislative instrument for social public services.
I therefore invite you to vote on the alternative resolution tabled by the Green Group.
Mr. President, the debates on GMOs must be based on irrefutable arguments, both from a scientific and legal perspective.
Legally, there were needed varied but strong arguments for member states wishing to restrict or ban GMOs on their territory.
The rapporteur has broadened the range of margins for manoeuvre.
More poor.
As for the scientific basis, it must also be irrefutable.
The Council has repeatedly questioned the EFSA's scientific assessments, which are still positive with regard to GMOs, unlike national scientific assessments.
To restore confidence, Commissioner, shouldn't we simply apply the existing legislation, which aims to provide a number of scientific guarantees, particularly in terms of long-term impact assessment?
Why did the Council's recommendations of October 2008 remain dead letters?
Madam President, Commissioner, first of all, I would like to thank our colleague Simon Bouzek for the wonderful work he has done.
These reflections have enriched the initial proposal and we can only congratulate them.
This report outlines an agency with multiplied resources, more in line with the missions assigned to it.
Recent events have shown us the need for closer cooperation between the European Union, the member states and the support of a strong agency.
Frontex finally gets the means to fulfill its missions.
By being able to acquire or rent its own equipment and by benefiting from the services of its own border guards, it becomes more independent and very effective.
New tasks are also assigned to it, such as organizing voluntary returns or processing personal data, so that we can fight against cross-border crime while protecting fundamental rights.
This extension of Frontex's scope of competence gives us the means to consider and address migration issues from a global perspective and not to be limited to a simple mechanical border management.
I approve of the possibility of exchanging personal data with other European agencies, including Europol.
Finally, the human dimension has taken its place in this report.
Strong recognition of human rights is guaranteed by the proposal to establish an advisory council within the Agency.

I can only welcome this comprehensive proposal, which is a step forward towards a healthy and responsible management of our external borders, in a context where migratory pressures are particularly strong and continue. Thank you.

Mr. President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr. Meyer, and the sometimes critical comments of my colleagues, but this activity report for 2010 is finally a great opportunity to talk about the Petitions Committee, because it remains too unknown.
However, it is the Commission, which has a direct, sometimes physical, link with the citizen, which can attend our debates itself.
It has undeniable legitimacy in Parliament, as well as a very long expertise, thanks to its direct relationship with the citizen.
Indeed, any petitioner can go to Parliament and defend his rights before the Committee on Petitions.
We can also welcome the serenity of the debates, despite the painful cases that are often dealt with.
This Commission represents Europe as it should be, listening to the problems of its citizens and united to find solutions and protect them.
Unfortunately, the means of action and the means of influence remain limited, particularly on the environmental risk of projects that are sometimes almost completed.
But I also see it when it comes to defending specific cases, such as family rights or children's rights in the event of a divorce.
We will also carry out a mission on this subject in November.
I also regret that national authorities do not always rush to provide us with all the necessary information.
I would like to thank the European Commission for the research and verification work it carries out, even if sometimes it could go further in the search for the truth.
I must also commend the constructive work we are doing with the European Ombudsman.
I call on the citizens to continue to solicit us through petitions as directly elected representatives.
Our role will always be to preserve your interests in strict respect of European law.
Madam President, Commissioner, I welcome this resolution on homelessness, because it is our responsibility to recall its extreme urgency.
First of all, let us note that what was a priority yesterday remains even more so today.

The lack of reliable definitions and statistical indicators on homelessness cannot prevent us from observing, as the crisis has helped, that the number of people living below the poverty line has increased, according to Eurostat, from 79 million in 2009 to 84 million, estimated in 2011.
Dear colleagues, three years ago, our Parliament, concerned with eradicating poverty, asked the Member States to put an end to the problem of the LDCs by 2015.
Today, we are even somewhat closer to our goal.
Has the year 2010, dedicated to the fight against poverty, actually been used by the member states to concretely address this great precariousness whose urgency has become permanent?
I really doubt it and I deeply regret it.

Finally, I would like to emphasize the need to develop a global, multi-sectoral strategy for homelessness, because of course there is poverty and lack of housing, but there are also family problems, health issues, various assumptions or personal vulnerability.
A comprehensive, effective, ambitious, but tailored approach is needed, which takes into account individuals, the heterogeneous nature of their path and their life breakdown.
This is a fundamental right, to say the least, that many precarious workers are deprived of.
Madam President, in recent years, as everyone has said, the European Union has been hit by unprecedented disasters, and the cities mentioned here would take up all the time of the debate.
I will still mention the AZDF explosion, whose ten-year anniversary we commemorated less than a week ago in Toulouse.
A reinforced reaction at the European level, as proposed in Mrs Gardini's report, represents a real opportunity to show solidarity among our populations.

For several years now, the Union has been trying to make this mutualization of our efforts operational, and it is now time to act together and stop waiting for a new disaster to strike our territories to learn from it.
Today, it is a matter of making our material, human and financial capabilities available to everyone in order to prevent new dramas from occurring.
Madam Commissioner, you said earlier that we need to anticipate risks.

It is truly regrettable that, in this context, the European Commission is considering withdrawing funding from the GMES satellite observation program, which is recognized by all as an essential instrument for the prevention and coordination of disaster response.
I urge the Commission to reconsider its position and to support these flagship programmes that give Europe an undeniable added value.
I would like to thank Mrs. Gardini for her very good report.
I hope we will adopt it, as it will pave the way for European solidarity at the service of the citizen. Thank you.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Minister, the number of poor and unemployed people is constantly increasing within the European Union.
More than forty-three million Europeans are threatened by food poverty.
The hour is serious.
Today, six member states want to end the food aid program without any replacement solution: Germany, Sweden, Denmark, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and the Czech Republic.
Of course, there is a decision by the Court of Justice and we must respect it.
However, Commissioner, last July, the Parliament called you out on the initiative of our group, the Greens, and you made relevant proposals to safeguard the programme.
The Greens are ready to work with you on long-term solutions, but since millions of people depend on this system, we cannot let the food aid budget be divided by four.
The urgency is real.

If nothing is done by the end of the year, more than three hundred million euros will be missing from the food bank, and nothing guarantees that national governments will be able to take over to fill this gap.
It is therefore a real question of solidarity between peoples.
Let's not leave an irresponsible government minority to deprive millions of Europeans of food aid, because it is above all a matter of survival.
The fight against poverty and malnutrition also requires a reform of the CAP.
We must fundamentally change our way of producing in order to bring food production closer to the population, especially the poorest, who also have the right to healthy and balanced nutrition.
Only a truly sustainable CAP will allow us to ensure that fewer Europeans will need food aid.
The Council must return to reason and allow those in need to resort to this vital help.
I am addressing in particular the future Danish government, which will be responsible for ensuring the presidency of the European Union as of January.
Return to reason. Do we need hunger riots in Europe to realize the urgent need to change our logic?

When it comes to saving banks, the Council has found solutions, but when it comes to saving food banks, there is no one left. The Parliament said a strong word last time: Humans are more important than finance.
Finance, it is high time to reaffirm it.
In any case, we will be very vigilant and we will not fail to renew our call in a constructive manner.
Six member states hold the fate of eighteen million Europeans in need in their hands.
Six member states that claim to do nothing more than legality.
Jurisprudence is one thing, humanism and political choices are another.
How can we not express our anger towards those who remain deaf to the cries of alarm launched by the associations that help the most deprived?
And do we, MEPs, representatives of all citizens, want a Europe where national selfishness sets policies, paying little attention to nationals of states in budgetary difficulties?
There is no question of renationalizing this aid.

No, let's keep this program, let's give it a stronger legal basis, but let's not let down those who, in the immediate future, in two thousand twelve, are counting on this aid in particularly difficult times of crisis. Thank you.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I will not go back over the cynicism with which the ArcelorMittal Group announced the closure of some of its tools in Europe, and in particular in Belgium, in Lige, which ultimately caused hundreds of direct layoffs and put several thousand indirect jobs at risk.
As a Lige, I share the astonishment and dismay of the five hundred and eighty-one workers who were laid off from their families.
But I also think of the severe restructuring announced by the steel group in France, Germany and Luxembourg.
The reasons always the same: poor prospects for the evolution of the steel market in Europe, strong competition with imports from China, Korea,
Russia and Brazil, the reduction of the automotive market and finally the competitiveness gap, for example, of the Liege site compared to the best factories in Northern Europe.
In addition, and despite a difficult year 2010, the financial center of the ArcelorMittal Belgian steel group generated a profit of 1.394 million euros.
He paid zero euros in taxes, or a tax rate of zero.
This is particularly shocking.
Group management is mainly financial, with a stop and go policy practiced on several sites.
And the closure of sites is nothing more, in the minds of its leaders, than a variable of economic adjustment where human stakes are of little importance.
This is no longer acceptable. So,
Mr. Commissioner, you spoke about the rules.
Wouldn't it be time for the Commission to develop a binding social responsibility code for multinational companies?

It has been six years since our Parliament adopted a report on relocations, the code of conduct for companies, the reimbursement of subsidies, and the mandatory consultation between companies, unions and public authorities.
Since then, it is clear that little concrete progress has been made on these various proposals.
So, what does the Commission plan to do about this and within what timeframe?
If we need to support the competitiveness of businesses and make Europe attractive in terms of economic investment, we also need to adopt a legislative framework.
Strong European to face relocations and restructuring, and to ensure full consideration of another capital human capital.
Finally, in the case of the Liege site, I hope it will be able to benefit from the intervention of the Globalization Adjustment Fund in order to compensate the laid-off workers. Thank you.

Madam President, dear colleagues, the wave of layoffs that is hitting workers throughout Europe must lead us to reflect on the role we, as political leaders, have to play in the face of multinational companies that are acting

Without any social ethics, they are making stock market layoffs and relocating to reduce costs, increase shareholder profits, and please rating agencies in disregard of social and environmental standards.

In its resolution of 20 September last on the future of the Globalization Adjustment Fund, the Parliament clearly expressed its desire to support, above all, the employees affected by the negative effects of restructuring.
But we also asked the Commission to ensure consistency between the EGF interventions and the European Union's industrial policy, particularly through the use of structural funds.

We also insisted that the future regulation of the EGF include improvements so that the Fund does not produce what it produces today on multinational companies, random, moral effects, as is the case with ArcelorMittal and Nokia.
Mr. Commissioner, we can no longer continue to look at the issue of structural funds and the globalization adjustment fund separately without
take into account the restructuring strategies of companies that benefit from them without examining the cost-benefit ratio of a policy, I repeat.
Mr. President, the European Ombudsman is brilliantly investigating complaints directed against the institutions and bodies of the European Union.

This instrument is both necessary to facilitate the free movement of our businesses and our citizens, but it is also a formidable guarantee, especially in the face of the Union's detractors, who too often say that the European Union is just a bureaucratic machine without control.
This is clearly nonsense. Europe is doing real work on itself, thanks to the European Ombudsman in particular.
But let me relay a remark that I greatly regret, in which the Commission is under the spotlight.
First, there are the numbers: sixty-five is the real number, not twelve, of the investigations opened by the Ombudsman concerning the European Commission.

There are also actors. Many companies come to us to explain their misunderstanding to the European Commission, which remains deaf to their requests, particularly with regard to access to documents. Similarly, with regard to the issue of transparency in decision-making,
Few people find their way around it.
And finally, from personal experience, I must confess that I was sometimes shocked by the reactions of some European Commission services present in the Petitions Committee.
As you know, the European Commission gives us its position on petitions, a position that we always take into account and which is necessary.

But it happens occasionally to see representatives of the European Commission who refuse to answer the questions of a member of parliament or who hide behind a wooden tongue almost as well as politicians, and this in front of citizens who plead for their cause.

I wanted to remind you that Europe must have a human face, that behind the administrative problems that the mediator raises and solves, there are Europeans relieved to be heard but disappointed by these
Citizens were then negatively marked by their confrontation with institutions, perhaps creating a feeling of revolt, misunderstanding and, in the long run, perhaps euroscepticism.
I sincerely hope that these criticisms and those of the Ombudsman against institutions in general will be heard. Thank you.
Madam President, professional mobility and growth, professional mobility and competitiveness of our European Union are the terms in which the subject of the day is posed.
We, the EPP group, have supported the report by our colleague Mrs. McClarkin, to which we have greatly contributed, and we obviously support it.

The main recommendation of this report is more professional mobility, more simplification and efficiency in the procedures for the recognition of professional qualifications, while guaranteeing patient safety and consumer safety.
But it is in terms of the path to growth that the issue of increasing professional mobility arises.
Moreover, the Single Market Forum, which took place in Krakow at the beginning of October, was not wrong.

who recalled that the member states must recognize the potential of the internal market to boost growth and job creation and must act to eliminate all obstacles to the completion of the internal market.
Similarly, the European Council of 23 October also set as one of the essential priorities to achieve intelligent, sustainable growth,
including the implementation of the twelve priority proposals of the Single Market Act, the twelve proposals made by the Commission under which the recognition of professional qualifications.

We can see that it is by increasing professional mobility that we can hope to unleash the growth potential that the internal market, our internal market of five hundred million inhabitants and five hundred million consumers, contains.

Professional mobility must therefore not only allow us to ensure, if we strengthen it, if we modernize it, if we improve it, the free movement of our compatriots within this market, but also allow us to acquire, we hope, additional growth margins.
This is why we, the EPP, have particularly supported the establishment of a voluntary professional training system.
Madam President, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Kaczmarek, for his excellent work.
I would like to say that it is important that every year the European Parliament takes stock of the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, insofar as
This Assembly plays a decisive role in strengthening the North-South dialogue and in establishing a development policy based on partnership and exchange.
2010 was a rich year for the APP, which met twice, as its predecessors said, in Spain and the DRC, to exchange, in particular,
on the impact of climate change in ACP countries, the impact of the global crisis, or on the freedom and independence of the media and food security.
But in 2010, the APP also sent its first election observation mission of this legislature.
I had the honor of co-chairing this mission in Burundi for the presidential elections with my colleague Assarid, a Member of Parliament for Mali.
This election observation mission was a real success.
We were able to meet all the political actors concerned and, thanks to the dual origin of this delegation, both TACP and European, we embodied a different legitimacy of European or African missions.
I therefore invite the APP office to renew this experience, which allows to put into practice the solidarity and privileged relations that unite the European Union with the ACP countries.
I would like to thank Mr. Dardenne for his report.
Of course, the crisis is economic and financial, but it is above all, for our fellow citizens, a social crisis.
Reducing the number of people in precarious situations by twenty million by 2020 requires strong measures involving the different levels of public power.

We must more than ever keep the commitments made by the European Union in 2010 during the European Year for Combating Poverty and Social Exclusion and during the creation of the European Platform against Poverty and Social Exclusion to have a European framework for social and territorial cohesion.

We must make European funds sustainable and optimize them, particularly the aid program for the most disadvantaged, which is currently maintained, improve social protection, support local or national initiatives that develop services for the care of children, the elderly and dependent people.
Poverty is a scourge to be fought at a horizontal level and it is time now to act to allow the most deprived to get out of their precariousness.

As political leaders at the European, national and local levels, we must take the necessary measures to ensure them, without discrimination, access to housing, access to health care, access to justice, access to education, access to a first job with a minimum income, perhaps indexed according to the poverty threshold of each Member State.
Investing in the promotion of innovation and social experimentation, as well as in the reduction of poverty, will allow us to implement a sustainable, intelligent and inclusive growth strategy.
The Europe we want and need at the moment is a Europe of solidarity.
Mr. President, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs. Levine, for her excellent work.

As rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development, I am pleased that the Committee on Fisheries has taken up the elements contained in our opinion, because it is crucial that the development dimension
should be taken into account in measures aimed at combating illegal fishing at a global level, in the name of policy coherence and close links with development policy.
Indeed, the fight against illegal fishing requires global solutions and the involvement of all states, including developing ones.
However, it is necessary that the technical and financial capabilities of the States are also taken into account in the actions to be carried out.
Indeed, the same constraints cannot be imposed on developed or developing countries without accompanying measures.
For example, small island states have very limited capacities.
They must therefore be supported in their efforts to combat illegal fishing.
This is why the Union will have to increase the financial envelope for the fishing sector when it concludes agreements in this area in developing countries.

Furthermore, it is crucial that measures aimed at combating illegal fishing are applied, as this practice undermines the development of countries insofar as it reduces the financial resources that these countries could draw from the economic activity of fishing.
However, these resources are necessary for developing countries to implement social, economic and educational policies.

Finally, it is important that the European Union promotes the involvement of civil society and businesses alongside the states that benefit from aid when implementing these measures to combat illegal fishing in developing countries.
A holistic approach is necessary to stem this scourge, which is illegal fishing. Thank you.
Mr. President, I would like to say that, to a large extent, thanks to these outermost regions, the European Union is the world's leading maritime power.
This is also a major asset for Europe, the development and implementation of a major policy on the sea, oceans and seabed is essential for tomorrow.
But I fear that with twenty or fifty million euros, this will not be enough to meet this great challenge.

The fight against illegal fishing is part of this major policy and it is urgent, at the European level, to find an adequate solution to this problem, particularly in the context of international cooperation.
I would also like to point out that the maritime areas of Guadeloupe, Guyana, Martinique, Mayotte and Runion are regularly violated and looted.
As the report does not mention this, I take this opportunity to draw the attention of my colleagues and the Commission to this particular problem.
Madam President, I would first like to congratulate the Polish Presidency, which has shown dynamism and voluntarism.
Next week, at the Council, our heads of state and government will have to make essential decisions for the future of the Eurozone and for the future of the Union.
They will also have to seriously address the revival of growth.

That said, we can see that today financial stability has become the top priority and that the pressures and tensions exerted from outside on the eurozone countries, but also within the eurozone, ruin our credibility and undermine confidence.
To hope for the return of confidence, we must restore financial stability, break the terrible progression of national deficits and sovereign debts.
Financial stability has indeed become the priority of priorities, it has become a burning obligation for everyone.
Our democracies have all committed to very courageous programs to clean up their public finances and reduce their debts. But financial stability is also the prerequisite for any recovery of growth.
But who says financial stability, budgetary discipline because it goes hand in hand, of course, must also say solidarity.
It seems important to us to ensure this double movement of financial stability, budgetary discipline and solidarity.
One last word on democracy.
Be careful not to disinform our democratic institutions.

Rather than thinking about resorting to a judicial mechanism, I would say to sanction in the case of budgetary deviations, let's think about control and sanction mechanisms exercised by democratic institutions.

To be completely frank, I am not the spokesperson for the French Minister of Foreign Affairs and, quite frankly, even though I belong to the same political group as him, I am not constantly in a position to relay the statements of the French Minister of Foreign Affairs.
To be completely honest once again, I am not aware of any recent statements by Alain Jupp to that effect.
I simply think that France's current position is to constantly affirm that the euro is truly the heart of our European construction, that the safeguarding of the euro means

That is to say, the safeguarding of this common project and the safeguarding of the European Union. In this movement to safeguard the euro, we must of course think about the future, think about the protection of the younger generations and the preservation of peace on our continent.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, tomorrow we will vote for the third time on the new cooperation instrument for the Mediterranean.
development, which provides accompanying measures in the banana sector for banana exporting ACP countries following the reduction of their tariff preferences, the BAM.
This aid program has a budget of 190 million euros and is aimed at ten ACP countries until 2013.
It is of crucial importance for our African and Caribbean partners, as the banana sector has considerable economic and social weight in these countries.
If all the Parliament's demands concerning the application of delegated acts have not been taken up for this instrument, I strongly regret it.
We have nonetheless managed to make progress.
Indeed, the text provides clear objectives and precise criteria for the allocation of resources to the Commission
The Commission also made a statement specifying the methodology used.

Moreover, we have a Council statement on the next multiannual financial framework, specifying that the latter would duly take into account delegated acts in the instruments of external aid after 2013.
Finally, in its resolution, the Parliament specifies and this point seems to me to be of the utmost importance that this is by no means a precedent.

I would like to tell you that I have just returned from Togo, where the twenty-second session of the ACP-EU APP took place, and I believe I can tell you that our ACP friends are counting on us in view of the urgency of the situation.
The funds should have been released two years ago.
We must be aware of the deplorable consequences for our ACP partners if the BAM ICD were rejected.
The situation of some farmers is dramatic, we can no longer wait and we must act accordingly.
I am counting on you to support the text. Thank you.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, our coordinator, Thys Berman, cannot finally be present tonight for personal reasons.
However, I know that he completely shares my analysis on this file.
The conciliation on this legislative package was long and tedious, and although the result on the human rights instruments and ICAI is satisfactory, we are far from the trivial instrument.

Thus, the compromise reached on this text disregards the mandate given to our negotiating team, which was to put Parliament on the same level as the Council in all programming decisions concerning the choice of strategic priorities and financial allocations.
because these are indeed the powers of our Assembly and the very spirit of the Treaty of Lisbon that are being discussed here.
The choice of programming priorities is a highly political decision on which our Assembly must have its say.
By categorically refusing to recognize any control power in Parliament and using shameful blackmail, the Council has once again shown a reprehensible ideological retreat.
But the member states must understand that the European Union's external action is now a shared competence between our institutions.
This is why our Parliament must remain sovereign and reject the proposal on the banana instrument.
This is the only way we can show the Council and the Commission that Parliament wants more transparency in Community decisions.
If we lose this battle, the absurd would be that we would have to wait for a new treaty to finally obtain the powers that Lisbon already provides.
Mr. President, at the risk of shocking the most federalist among you, I think that a defense policy is a highly national policy.
They meet the specific strategic, diplomatic and security needs of each nation.
Sharing capabilities is nothing more than an amputation of sovereignty, the single market for military equipment a big joke when some member states think that their
The defense guaranteed in Washington is primarily equipped with American equipment, Europe being unable, in this area as in many others, to impose community preference.
Regarding the common security challenges of the member states of the Union, there is nothing that cannot be resolved through intergovernmental cooperation, apart from any intervention from Brussels.

I am sorry, but entrusting these areas to Ms. Ashton would be like recognizing that Moody's and Standard Poor's have legitimacy in judging our economic policies, and accepting that the Mercosur couple can impose a German Europe on twenty-seven peoples is pure mental aberration.

For thirty years and even more since the disappearance of the Soviet threat, defense budgets have been the first to be sacrificed on the altar of budgetary rigor to the point of making most of our military tools

Deficient or outdated, and this, in the name of purely financial considerations, each expecting from the neighbor or the supposed American big brother the efforts that he is no longer ready to make himself.
But you are mistaken in your voice.

It is only by returning to independent and resolute national policies that we can individually equip ourselves with the necessary means, not only for our national security and interests, but also for the cooperation of these means to meet common challenges.
An addition of weaknesses and gaps has never made a strength.

Mr. President, I would like to express the support of the French delegation of the EPP group for the treaty on European stability, coordination and governance and its support for the main conclusions reached by the Council.
Let's not be mistaken.
This treaty represents an important step towards greater economic and budgetary integration, towards greater financial stability.
Let's repeat it here.
There can be no sustainable recovery of growth and employment without the consolidation of our public finances.
Of course, growth is not decreed, it is not a treaty that can revive growth on its own.
But a treaty, that is to say a set of rules and mutual commitments, can bring trust and accountability.

And as the president of the socialist group thought it was good to introduce political politics in this hemicycle, and by alluding to the upcoming French presidential campaign, mentioning the socialist candidate in this French presidential election, I wanted to reply.
We, the EPP, consider the statements of the French socialist candidate, who said he wanted to renegotiate the treaty concluded by twenty-five, to be totally irresponsible.
Take the file What and with I.
These words are totally irresponsible.
They pay little attention to the French state's words and respect for the French state's commitments.
Madagascar, one of the poorest countries in the world, is experiencing a political crisis whose solution will be the implementation of the roadmap up to the presidential and legislative elections.
The country's growth is negative.
Normally, our contribution is around fifty percent of the country's budget.
The European Union has rightly suspended its budgetary support for the GDP of the ninth and tenth EDF, but not for the MDGs.
Meanwhile, the population is suffering and companies based in Madagascar are sometimes exploited despite this.

While supporting your position, we want you to carry out your full efforts with SADEC so that the legal mess concerning the return of the former president is resolved as soon as possible, as it is one of the most sensitive elements of the implementation of this roadmap.

I would like to hear your opinion on the subject and also to inform you that the European Union-Madagascar Friendship Group, which we have just created in the European Parliament, is available to work with you and the Commission in the interest of the Malagasy people and in the defense of the values of our Union.

Mr. President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Iturgaiz, for the quality of his work, for the long negotiation work he had to carry out and for the patience he was able to demonstrate.

We are finally coming to the vote on this report, which is extremely important, because it allows us to bring up in this hemicycle, with the Commission and the Council, the difficulties and fears of our fellow citizens.
This is further proof, if any, of the effectiveness of the right to petition in Europe.
Environmental petitions are majority, and waste is a major concern of our fellow citizens.
This subject must respond to a social problem.
We consume everything.
We are only now realizing that what we do not consume, we throw away.
This awareness must be absolutely strengthened among citizens, that is clear.
But this report is also a reminder for the member states.
It is still worrying to see that the states do not seem to have control over the situation.
Only six member states have transposed the waste directive and the waste framework directive in time.
The number of complaints received on the subject sometimes demonstrates the lack of transparency in the choice of landfill location.
Finally, and this is the most worrying, organized crime seems to do what it wants.
A market of seventy-five billion euros inevitably attracts greed.
The states must send a strong signal.
Sanctions must be increased against companies that distort public contracts to get rich.
This report is a warning signal to the States, but the European Commission must also play its role and verify the proper application of the waste directives.
This file must be made visible, but also credible.
If nobody plays the game, we will continue to waste time and money in verification and counter-verification procedures that risk taking years.
Let's listen to the petitioners'message and stop this waste as soon as possible.
Mr. Commissioner, Mr. rapporteur, I would first like to congratulate Mr. Nicholson for the courage he had in the face of the Council and the Commission.
Despite this, I fear that what we have achieved will not allow for a balance between producers and industrialists.
This agreement reminds me of the illusion that children tell of a paradise where vegetarian lions would eat grass next to sheep.
I don't believe it for a second. Since 2003, Mrs. Fischer-Bowles has done everything to ideologically destroy milk quotas.
In October 2009, the Court of Auditors, despite everything, recognized the effectiveness of these milk quotas.

Today, we are in a situation that will be even more dramatic, and we see what is happening in Denmark, where the strongest farms, with the increase in production, are all in a situation of bankruptcy, with the fall in land prices by forty.
Do we want this at the European level?
I say no, we need to control production with the participation of public authorities. Thank you.
Madam Commissioner, the standards for the protection of third-country personal data still differ considerably from European standards.
However, it is our duty to ensure that our European minimum standards of protection, which we claim to be, are respected and guaranteed to European citizens.
It is essential that personal data is processed fairly and collected for specific and legitimate purposes.
European citizens must be guaranteed the right to access and correct personal data concerning them, as well as to file a legal appeal in case of violation of their rights.
We must act to enable European and international standards to coexist and resolve a legal conflict that could potentially be detrimental to European citizens.
European legislation alone is not enough.
It must be articulated and coexist intelligently with international standards, because we cannot do without our duties and commitments to European citizens.
This situation echoes other debates within this chamber.
It reminds us of the relevance of projects such as the establishment of a European program for monitoring the financing of terrorism.

Such a system would allow us to have a tool that has proven its effectiveness in the United States, while fully respecting domestic law and therefore the protection of the personal data of European citizens.
European institutions must continue their commitment to this and fully assume their protection standards. Thank you.
Mr. President, first of all, thank you to the rapporteurs for their work.

In response to the crisis, the European Union has just spent more than a year strengthening its economic governance to avoid macroeconomic imbalances and budget deficits that are too significant and threaten the European economy, but this has not prevented social exclusion or an increase in unemployment.
It is time, no, it is urgent now that the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy are an absolute priority for the European Commission and for the Member States, in a perspective of growth.

Each state will have to implement a national employment plan, which means that the emphasis will have to be on so many subjects, such as pelle ml, training, retraining, microcredit, apprenticeships, paid internships, etc.

And Commissioner Andor recalled this earlier: we have twenty-three million unemployed people in Europe, but also twenty-three million SMEs and twenty-three billion European funds dedicated to employment that are unused.
We could almost make it a twenty-three strategy.
And that is not counting the sixty billion euros of unallocated cohesion funds.
In Denmark and the Netherlands, social initiatives have been taken and have proven their effectiveness based on flexicurity.
Let's take inspiration from it.

This also means that our overall social policy must be more adapted, with more advantageous social incentives than those related to unemployment and active support for all socially virtuous companies.
We had poverty reduction targets to be achieved by 2020, but we already know that they will not be achieved due to the lack of strong and adequate measures taken by the member states.

Our role as parliamentarians must therefore be fully exercised, and it is our responsibility to demand that the same energy put into taking strong economic governance measures also be directed at ambitious, effective and binding social governance measures.
Madam President, the cause of women is undoubtedly very much owed to Europe.
The principle of gender equality was already enshrined in the Treaty of Rome and has since been reaffirmed in numerous treaties.
Gender equality is a fundamental value of our European project.
As a result, Europe has always worked in a very proactive way for gender equality, for the cause of promoting women and
Little by little, progress has been made.
Many legislative instruments have been adopted, directives have been put in place.
There has been an extremely active and vigilant committee on women's rights and gender equality within our Parliament for many years.
A European institute for gender equality has been created.
Programs are being implemented, and financial resources are being voted on year after year.
More recently, on March 2nd, we had the opportunity to celebrate for its second edition the European Day of Equal Treatment, Equal Pay.
The European Equal Pay Day. Undoubtedly, the legislative arsenal exists, the European will has been realized several times.
However, it is clear that the fight remains topical, the fight for gender equality and in particular for equal pay.
There is still an average wage gap of around 17% in all European Union countries.
Women still earn 17% less than men at equal work.
This is of course completely unacceptable.
The Parliament's Women's Committee is currently working on a draft resolution to call on the European Commission to revise the 2006 directive on equality of opportunities.
treatment, which is one of the most worrying and most at the heart of the concerns and demands of European women in all our societies.

On another subject, that of the introduction of quotas, both within the decision-making bodies of large companies and within political life, I come from a country, France, which adopted a long time ago, already more than
Ten years of binding rules on quotas in political life and more recently, about a year ago, a law for the establishment of quotas in the boards of directors of large companies.
France is not the only country, of course, to have opted for such legislation.
So, what is the balance after a few years of application in one case, a few months in the other? It is clear that things have moved, that things have advanced.
So, a necessary evil.
Quotas produce effect.

Madam Commissioner, you have recently taken an important step towards the establishment of quotas at European level in the decision-making bodies of large companies by launching this large public consultation aimed at collecting opinions on the actions to be implemented, the possible legislative actions to be implemented.
On this subject, you will have my full and complete support. Thank you.
Mr. President, Commissioner, on the occasion of this resolution, allow me to address two topics firstly the issue of water management in the world and in Europe.
Europe, and then a question to the European Commission, so that actions can allow us to respond to a number of our concerns related to the common agricultural policy.
The stakes, as we know, are water, the big deal of the 21st century.
It is because we will have answers that we will have peace in the world and in Europe.
We know the stakes, we know the stakes in terms of management, we know the stakes in terms of food safety.
And on the occasion of this forum, which, as our colleague Rivasi recalled, too many purely commercial concerns are at the heart of the discussion that has begun in recent days in Marseille.
One question: why is there no coherence between water management and water-related resources and the common agricultural policy? Because
Nothing in the CAP reform is indicated regarding this management, as our colleague Sarbu said earlier.
So give us some answers.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to thank the rapporteur and our assistants for the work done.
This report now bears its name very well, namely to remove obstacles to citizenship.
Europe is a wonderful project, but it is too often noticed that it is not yet perfectly defined.
Let's take the economic crisis as an example.
It has revealed our weaknesses and allowed us to build the regulatory institutions of our single market more solidly.
For the European citizen, it is the same.
The Petitions Committee, a true complaints office, records the complaints of our fellow citizens every day.
In three days, the European Citizens'Initiative will complete this system.
Despite all our policies that call for mobility, membership, European values, and exchanges, there are still far too many obstacles to the exercise of citizenship.
And a citizen who does not feel European is a citizen who will not go to vote, it is a citizen who will not see the interest that Europe represents in his everyday life.
With my colleagues from the EPP, we have made a lot of proposals, the most numerous, and I would like to thank them for that.
This report must produce a sense of belonging and European identity that we must recreate and maintain through these measures.
Our Europe must be a Europe that protects.
Commissioner Viviane Reding made twenty-five very concrete proposals in favor of citizens.
They are essential to restore trust between the citizen and Europe.
But the proposals contained in this report reflect other expectations of our fellow citizens: online shopping, moving, children's rights, employment,
Citizen participation, care abroad, twinning, minority rights, etc. We still have too much trouble taking full advantage of the capabilities offered by Europe.
Rights are used, claims are heard.
We are the relays here.
The European Year of Citizenship in 2013 will have to demonstrate to citizens that with free movement, there is also free use of rights in Europe.
I believe that taxation is an interesting tool for changing behaviors.

I believe that energy consumption must be framed with an indicative price signal for the consumer and, above all, I think that, in order to avoid any distortion in the internal market, we must try to bring our tax practices closer together.
The principle of proportionality of the different levels of taxation of energy products therefore seems to me to be a necessity.
In the case that concerns us, for example, this would put an end to diesel tourism, which we are currently witnessing and which is not an acceptable thing.
I therefore share the philosophy of the Commission's proposal to revise the directive.
However, if we need to achieve our goals in terms of reducing CO2 emissions or energy efficiency, our collective decisions must not punish citizens or sectors particularly exposed to the

Price volatility on the global markets, and I am thinking of the agricultural sector, for example. The proposal for a directive will have an impact, certainly differentiated according to the level of taxation of each Member State, but still an impact on the price of diesel.
The question is who will ultimately have to bear this price increase?
Are there real, feasible, realistic, and accessible alternatives for consumers?
As a shadow rapporteur in the Environment Committee, I support an ambitious but above all sustainable position for all.

I therefore advocate for greater progressiveness and the entry into force of the proposal and its principle of proportionality in 2030, with a new impact study that updates the one on which the Commission is based and which was carried out five years ago.

Earlier, right here, we had a debate on the wave of layoffs in Europe due to the economic crisis, particularly at Arcelor, a multinational present in nine European member states, which is restructuring its production tool in Europe in the face of a downward steel demand.

Since the closure of two blast furnaces in Belgium, Luxembourg and the safeguarding of a blast furnace in France, it is estimated that nearly six direct jobs would be threatened for the year two thousand twelve.

Beyond unacceptable practices such as stop and go, a practice that should be better regulated, it is the more global issue of European steel industry and adaptation to change that requires extremely urgent responses.

Six months ago, the Commission announced the need to conduct, in light of the economic crisis, a new consultation exercise for responsible management of restructuring with social partners and public authorities.
My question is simple, six months later, where are we?

Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to distort the allegations of unfounded circulation in France from five hundred million to one million fake biometric passports that would circulate in our country.
France takes the risks of identity document fraud very seriously.
It does not take crimes in this area lightly.
At the initiative of his government, identity theft is a crime punishable by one year in prison and a fine of fifteen euros.
The conditions for issuing identity cards have been simplified, which has allowed the prefectures to allocate additional resources to combat this fraud.
Thus, in each prefecture, a fraud referent is appointed.
In addition, the security provisions for issuing identity cards have been strengthened.
For example, the civil status data provided can be verified between administrative services as much as possible in a dematerialized manner in order to limit the risks of falsification.
Some birth certificates are also issued on secure paper.
The same rigor applies to home documents.
The Ministry of the Interior has committed to increased security of home documents with the inclusion of a barcode.

The classic processing of a title application includes the authorized consultation of useful files, the comparison of all the parts produced during previous title applications, and the possible authentication of supporting parts.

The security of the issuance of securities is also guaranteed by the double appearance of the applicant at the time of the application submission and then the withdrawal of the security, as well as the withdrawal of two fingerprints.
Not to mention the reinforced checks for the renewal of lost and stolen titles for comparative purposes with the data kept by the prefectures, I conclude.

Furthermore, France reports to international cooperation bodies and in particular to Interpol, I conclude, Mr. President, I have almost finished the passports issued or lost and stolen so that they are not used for fraudulent purposes.
My dear colleagues, France, like the rest of the European Union, is committed
Mr. President, Commissioner, first of all, a note: our fellow citizens increasingly want to find and consume locally and seasonally produced food, for health and quality reasons in particular.
We must find ways to enable farmers to respond effectively and quickly to this growing demand.

We must support the establishment of local infrastructure for producers, such as maintaining local slaughterhouses, which, while guaranteeing rigorous health control, allow the development of local short circuits and strengthen direct sales.
Support for local agriculture and direct sales must help producers market their products and make them known to consumers.
Strengthening these direct relationships will allow farmers to retain a larger part of the added value created on their farms.

Direct sales within the farm must be encouraged and facilitated, and collective actions of farmers who want to open collective sales points that allow local consumers to offer a wider range of products must be supported.

The European Commission must facilitate the emergence, sustainability and development of direct sales systems by delivery to consumers, such as the AMAP in France, which allow nearly three farmers to supply sixty families.

Finally, the member states must be able to add other criteria, particularly concerning the size of the farm, the volume of production or the traditional nature of the product, to define local agriculture. Thank you.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I am pleased that this amending budget concerning the financing of ITER, which was voted on by a large majority in the Committee on Budgets on 29 March,
By financing this additional cost, we avoid throwing away a strategic basic research project in which the European Union plays a leading role and we honor our international promises.
Let us recall that none of the seven partners of the Euratom community have questioned their overall contribution to the project.
Japan, despite the Fukushima tragedy, has decided to scrupulously respect its budget commitments in ITER.
Without this agreement, hundreds of researchers would have had to suspend their work and the ITER project would have experienced damaging delays.
Today, a thousand people are working for ITER in Cadarache.
From 2015 to 2017, the construction phase of the buildings and the assembly of the machine could mobilize up to four people on this site.
In conclusion, Mr. President, ITER is a source of pride for Europe and the symbol of our excellence.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. rapporteur, thank you for the work we have done together.
The European Union needs a manifesto, a common political vision on the major environmental challenges by 2020 and beyond.
This is the whole point of launching a seventh environmental action program, by synchronizing existing financial frameworks and mobilizing new funding resources.
This program must guarantee consistency and articulation between the European Union's environmental strategies and sectoral policies, whether it is agriculture,
fishing, research and innovation, health, transport, regional development, land use planning and urban policies, of course.
Despite the economic crisis that is undermining the European Union, we must not give in to a short-term vision and abandon any ambition in the environmental and climate fields.
Inaction would be fatal.
The stakes are too high, particularly with regard to the effective use of our resources and the valuation of natural capital.
We must therefore resolutely invest in the sustainable economy and eco-innovation, which are sources of growth, competitiveness and employment.
It is up to us to promote eco-design, recycling, but also the environmental display of products in order to avoid waste and bad consumption choices.
We cannot ignore this environmental education necessary for European citizens.
The environmental action programme is a political programming instrument, but it is also a communication tool.
It must provide the necessary readability and predictability to national and local administrations, citizens, but also entrepreneurs and investors on the environmental choices of the European Union.
European regulation should not become a punishment or a straitjacket.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, in the face of the profound changes to which our world is subject today, the EU must reform its system of generalized preferences.
Like any compromise, this one does not deviate from the rule.
If it is satisfactory from a strictly commercial point of view, it is far from perfect, because we must keep in mind that this regulation is addressed to developing countries.
By developing its new paradigm of differentiation, the Commission says it wants to refocus its action in favor of the poorest countries.
This seems quite sustainable at first glance.
To do this, the Commission has nonetheless developed a strictly accounting vision based solely on the GDP per capita criterion.
We can see the limit of this approach.
What about the many middle-income developing countries whose economies are not very diversified and are vulnerable to climate hazards?
The compromise reached with the Council does not answer this question, and that is why I call on my colleagues to vote in favour of the three amendments that will be tabled on this text.
Mr. Commissioner, the problem of the availability of public consultations in the different languages of the European Union is unfortunately not new.

This is a crucial issue in my opinion, and that is why I have not only asked several written questions to the European Commission since 2008, but I have also personally questioned Mr. Barroso in writing.

Indeed, the Commission must comply with the principle of equal treatment and access to information for all European citizens, as recalled by the European Community Court of First Instance in its ruling of 20 November 2008.
I was not at all satisfied with the European Commission's response, according to which public consultations do not claim to provide a fully representative picture of all opinions.
According to this response, the Commission takes into account the fact that some positions and views may be overrepresented at the expense of others.
That is not an answer.
I wonder about the criteria that would allow measuring the overrepresentation of the European population.
If written consultations are not representative due to the sole availability in English, for example, they fail to achieve their goal of consulting European citizens.
Thus, the result gives a bad indication and should therefore not be used by the European Commission.
If we want to keep written consultations as a tool at the basis of the European Commission's legislative proposals, we must guarantee a democratic, transparent and fair process for all citizens.

Thus, if the European Commission makes the choice of written consultations, it must take its responsibilities and ensure the necessary resources for multilingualism and the translation of questionnaires.
In conclusion, I would like to add that multilingualism is not the only obstacle.

The analysis should also include the too short deadlines for submitting contributions, as well as the few resources deployed by the Commission to communicate on these consultations, which are unfortunately mainly accessible to insiders. Thank you.
The proposed regulation aims to give the European Commission more powers to control national budgets and economic policies.
The rules will be stricter and failing states will be forced to make budget cuts and structural reforms by the technocrats of Brussels in order to restore their financial balance.
This reinforced surveillance is called supervision.
States will be punished, fined, and, so to speak, reduced, and financial sanctions will be strengthened and more automatic.
Even if some amendments aim to prevent budgetary austerity alone through growth measures, your proposals are only there to pass the pill.
Growth, as you know, like me, is not decreed.
Without consulting the people and with the complicity of Brussels, we are definitively losing our budgetary sovereignty, our freedom to choose our policies.

And when, little by little, according to the Chinese thief's technique, the European bureaucratic, technocratic and totalitarian state has finally been formed, we will have lost our freedom as a people altogether.
Mr. President, without disregarding the importance of the economic choices we must assume, I would like to emphasize a more political remark in the context of this debate.
In recent weeks, we have once again seen evidence of the double language of some great European leaders or those who believe themselves to be such.
While everyone keeps advocating for a coordination of economic, budgetary and fiscal policies that are finally worthy of the name, and this requirement even appears as a condition
This is a sine qua non condition for the survival of the Eurozone, and once they are well established, Mr. Krois Malin will be able to criticize the balanced recommendations from
The Commission to free itself from certain commitments or, in the worst case, to raise public opinion against these Brussels'doubts, as they say.
This irresponsible attitude could be amusing if we were not in such a tragic situation.
I will tell you quite clearly: our debates on stability, the necessary consolidation of public finances or the efforts to be made in terms of growth are indeed doomed to
failure if the mistakes of the past in terms of debt and public deficit do not end, and if the governments of the member states continue in their misfortune.
We are currently playing with fire.
European discipline must work for everyone, without exception, even for the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg.
This requires a minimum of courage and our public opinions are ready for it, much more than some of their leaders want to believe.
One last word to Ms. Goulard, otherwise I have to show her the blue card. Finally, I would say to Ms. Goulard, in redemption, there is redemption.

Mr. President, I would first like to commend the determination of the European Commission and, in particular, yours, Commissioner, for tirelessly putting the recovery and deepening of the internal market at the top of the European agenda.

As you recalled, Commissioner, it has been more than two years since both the Commission and the European Parliament have been working to identify the missing links in the internal market, to identify the stakes and sectors for which more internal market is needed, more internal market for more growth, more competitiveness, more jobs.

The European Council, for its part, also later ended up emphasizing the importance it attached to the rapid and effective implementation of the twelve priority proposals for the internal market, the twelve levers for growth.
Rather than constantly trying to invent new growth instruments, we have every interest in working with the toolbox we already have.

We are therefore seizing the opportunity of the resolution, which will be put to the vote of our Assembly tomorrow, to send a strong political message to the Member States, calling for more speed and efficiency in the transposition of the directives already
More mobilization and commitment in the newly opened projects, I will mention only one, that of strengthening worker mobility, more ease of movement, more fluidity of movement.
We will welcome with great interest, Commissioner, the second stage of the Single Market Act that you will present after the summer.
We will be able to demonstrate both political voluntarism and the ability to put pressure on the member states.
We have known about the Mediator scandal some time ago.
We now have the scandal of breast implants, which unfortunately highlights, as you said, Commissioner, the malfunctions of European health safety.
This scandal of breast implants, these fourteen years of scams from 1996 to 2010, goes unpunished.
These are five hundred prostheses worn in the world, these eight implant removals, forty-eight proven cancer cases.
Finally, three complaints have been filed. These numbers are frightening, shocking.

How, despite the warnings from the US Medicines Agency, the FDA, Commissioner, and the numerous complaints and convictions for prosthetic rupture filed in Great Britain and France in particular, how were national and European agencies able to bypass such a scam?
This tragedy immediately led us to think about improving the European system for controlling medical devices, as you just explained.
Mr. Commissioner, today we must build a new system capable of avoiding the scandal, but it is a new system that must be built.
You have indicated that this new legislation is announced for the autumn.
As co-author of this resolution, I am obviously satisfied.
But, Commissioner, you seem to want to take into account a large part of our concerns as stated in this resolution.
So why make an exception that is unacceptable to many of the parliamentarians present here?
Why not want to create a marketing authorization for the most risky class III medical devices?
Mr. Commissioner Dalli, can you explain your position to me?
Mr. President, we are currently experiencing a situation with an increase in production of more than two and a half. At the same time, manufacturers are lowering prices.
In Italy, Germany, England and all European countries, prices are falling.
This means very clearly that prices are linked to production volume, and we need to organize production volumes and prices at the same time.
At the same time, today, producers are victims of an increase of more than forty-four of vegetable proteins and thirty of the price of cereals.
