The Parliament has already voted on the need to ensure that the added value is distributed among producers and that farmers are not victims of companies and large retailers.

Therefore, I ask the Commission today, but also the Council, to reconsider the questioning of production control, but at the same time, I say very clearly that the Member States must clean up their own backyard, because there are countries that have respected the quota rules and others that have not.
And that is also what has caused these quotas to be called into question.
So there is a double responsibility between the Commission and the Member States.
Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, a single European railway area is a beautiful European integration policy.
This is a beautiful policy in which European construction is at the heart of the daily concerns of Europeans.

Too often criticized because, in a state of crisis, Europe, with this directive, finally shows the way for a major sustainable transport policy and opens the field for a major railway investment policy for employment.

I welcome the main measures taken in the organization of the rail network, the establishment of national regulators in each Member State, the creation of a five-year multiannual investment contract, thus stipulating the financing commitments of the

railway infrastructure, but also I welcome the establishment of transparency of financial flows between managers and operators within the framework of integrated companies. The reminder of non-discriminatory access to certain

Finally, I am pleased with the confirmation, desired by the European parliamentarians, of certain guarantees, particularly on the social level, for example the absence of a reference to the minimum service, as well as the total unbundling between the manager and the operator.

But let me mention a requirement that we stop considering, in particular, on the part of the European Commission, the liberalization of the railway sector as the only strategic horizon for the development of a single railway area, and thus decide on an integrated European investment strategy that favors employment in Europe.
Finally, I would like to ask you a question, Commissioner Callas.
This is three days after the European Council of 28 and 29 June, after the validation of a growth pact of one hundred and twenty billion euros to boost the European economy.
Notably through investment in infrastructure. Commissioner, can you tell us what amounts the European railway sector is likely to benefit from within the framework of this growth pact?
Madam President, tomorrow we will have a debate on ACTA, but I would like to address a question, certainly peripheral, but extremely important to me on this subject.
These are the words Commissioner de Gucht made in the International Trade Committee on Wednesday, June 20.

I quote: If you decide to vote against before the European Court of Justice rules, let me tell you that the Commission will, however, continue to pursue the current procedure before the Court of Justice
We are committed to this.
A negative vote will not stop the proceedings before the Court of Justice.

Not only do these statements seem to me to be a misunderstanding of the treaties, but above all, and this is what I want to denounce, they testify to an unacceptable disregard for the European Parliament, for democracy in general and for the citizens we represent.
This is at a time when European citizens, as a whole,
Thank you, Mr. President. At this time, a lot has been said.
Mr. Commissioner, I would like to thank you very warmly.
Thanks to your stubbornness and your procedural tricks, you allow us to prove the importance of the European Parliament as a co-legislator.
Thank you, Commissioner, for pushing hundreds of thousands of citizens to take to the streets and two million eight hundred to sign petitions.
They discovered that democracy is at stake here, that we, the European elected officials, are the representatives of the people, their representatives.
Thank you again to the millions of internet users who have followed the debates and votes in committee and who are still following us today.
I welcome them. It is a fresh air in our institutions, which is too often perceived as technocratic.
Thank you, Commissioner, but in a democracy, there is another principle.
This is the fundamental principle, that of responsibility.
Tomorrow, we will take our responsibility and I would also like to thank you tomorrow for taking responsibility for your failure, the failure of your working method.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, I am speaking on behalf of Maurice Ponga, rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development on Mr. Gallagher's report.
It seemed important to me to recall that the European Union, when it wants to sanction a country that practices unsustainable fishing, must take into account its level of development.

Indeed, in the name of the principle of policy coherence with development objectives, it is crucial, in my opinion, that the measures adopted in the field of fisheries do not call into question the development plans and strategies implemented by the European Union in these countries.
Mr. Gallagher's draft report takes up this important idea for our development committee, providing that the measures must not be unjustified or even discriminatory.

I therefore invite the European Commission, when it adopts such measures, to respect this principle of policy coherence with development objectives and to duly take into account the level of development and the vulnerability of countries. Thank you.
This third reform of the common fisheries policy must not be done again against the interests of fishermen.
No, not all fishermen are these sea plunderers, solely responsible for the poor state of stocks, as claimed by all categories of fishing, environmental organizations and the European Commission.

Of course, we must preserve fish stocks, but we must also allow our fishermen to make a living from their activity and preserve the economic fabric, dynamism and cultural identity of our coastal regions.
However, the main measures of the European executive are once again aimed at reducing the number of fishermen to reach the mythical maximum sustainable yield.
I would like to remind you that the French fleet has decreased by more than fifty percent since 1980.

The Commission proposes, in particular, the implementation of transferable individual quotas, a guarantee of industrialization and the concentration of the sector, or the total ban on discards, which professionals consider unrealistic.
This reform project is probably suitable for the industrial fleet, but in its current state it would mean the planned death of what remains of local and artisanal fishing.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I would like to congratulate the EPP rapporteur, our colleague Karins, for this difficult report, given the sensitive nature of bilateral energy negotiations between European countries and third countries.
The agreement reached in the trialogue will allow for the rapid implementation of the Commission's draft decision, and, out of pragmatism, we can only be pleased about it.
The energy Europe is progressing, certainly not fast enough, but it is progressing.
The European Union, which is a strong energy importer, is structurally dependent on certain supplier countries.

In order to have a more European reflection on our energy strategy, it had become necessary to disseminate information on energy agreements more widely to the European Commission, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity.
The establishment of an information mechanism on intergovernmental agreements will therefore improve transparency in the energy market and thus allow for the anticipation of energy supply problems.
I am pleased that this decision does not create an obligation with regard to agreements between commercial companies.
In times of crisis and given the stakes in terms of competition and competitiveness, we had to protect the interests of our companies and the rules for the protection of private contracts.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, I would like to thank our two rapporteurs for the work they have done on this file.

It was necessary because we were starting from a very far-reaching point with the Commission's basic proposal: no specific mention of the outermost regions directly affected by competition from Latin American countries, no automatic triggering

The stabilization mechanism, no possibility offered to our Assembly to request the opening of a safeguard investigation, no consideration of social and environmental standards as constituting an unfair competitive advantage.
This is why it is extremely important that tomorrow's vote validates the progress made on these points in the Committee on International Trade.
Despite everything, this is not enough, because we know that the triggering thresholds of these two regulations are so high that they make these mechanisms practically inapplicable.
Moreover, the Commission must provide an additional financial envelope to support the competitiveness of Community banana production.
Let us keep in mind that many jobs are at stake in these European regions, which already have record unemployment rates.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to thank Charles Goerens for his excellent report.
As we all know here, the European Union provides more than half of the total world development aid, and yet, as the MDGs expiring in two thousand and fifteen approach, even if some objectives seem
Once we have achieved this, we must ask ourselves how to improve our aid, make it more coherent with our trade policy, our agricultural policy, and our foreign policy.
The future of European development policy must be based on precise, measurable commitments and on a short and medium-term timetable.

The economic crisis, climate change, the power of emerging countries, and land grabbing force us to define new priorities to ensure food security, access to energy resources, and access to healthcare.

Of course, there is a European consensus, but we must rethink European and international institutional systems in environmental and social matters, drawing inspiration from decision-making bodies such as the WTO, for example.
Finally and above all, we must explain to our fellow citizens that the development of third countries is not only charity and solidarity, but also a source of development for us.
You just have to look at the markets that are opening up for Europeans in emerging countries, China, Brazil and India.
2015 will also be an opportunity to take better account of the geostrategic evolution of recent years, because today's emerging countries were not yet developing countries.
Now, as an unavoidable economic power, these countries must also contribute to international aid.
The European Union must promote responsible development aid at both European and international levels.

The year 2015 will be more than a deadline, it will be a unique opportunity to rethink development aid, not as mere financial assistance, but as support for responsible development projects, both at the social and environmental level.

I therefore join my colleagues from other groups and those of the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions in asking that 2015 be designated the European Year of Development and, above all, of responsible development.
Mr. President, the agenda for change proposed by the Commission raises, in my opinion, many questions, the main one being the concrete implementation of the principle of differentiation.

The Commission wishes that from 2014, the choice of countries in which the European Union will invest its development aid will be based on the mechanical application of the simple criterion of wealth per capita.
As Mrs. Ashton recalled, these issues are not only accounting, but deserve a real political debate on defining our priorities in terms of international cooperation.
Moreover, this differentiated approach is not, in my opinion, in line with the spirit of the Cotonou Agreement.

I am convinced that ACP countries that have achieved positive economic performance should be encouraged in their transition towards more sustainable growth. These countries should not be unduly sanctioned for having managed to ensure growth through discipline, good governance and prudent economic policies.
Madam President, Commissioner, let us welcome the initiative taken by Jacques Delors twenty years ago, at the very moment when the Berlin Wall fell.
Despite all these advances that we have seen since the beginning of our debate, it is clear that the Single Act is now synonymous with injustice, inequality and economic liberalism.
I would like to hear from you, Mr. Barnier, Mr. Commissioner, to tell us how we are going to build together a more just Europe, a facilitating Europe, a protective Europe.

There are a number of paths and I would like to hear your thoughts on these paths that are at the heart of the economic and social crisis as we unfortunately know it fiscal harmonization, public services,
minimum wage protectors in Europe, the establishment of enhanced cooperation that creates jobs, facilitating cross-border cooperation and developing a fair trade policy.
These are the stakes, I believe, twenty years later, that are before us.
I am counting on you, Commissioner, to carry out this beautiful European construction policy together.

Mr. President, as a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I have been closely interested in the report by my colleague Regina Bastos on the twenty main issues of concern for citizens and businesses.
And we discussed this report in connection with our debate on the twenty years of the internal market.
Twenty years ago, the free movement of goods, people, services and capital was supposed to be able to fully exercise itself within our living space, exchange, and internal market.

I was particularly interested in the fact that the recognition of professional qualifications is at the top of the concerns expressed by our European fellow citizens and that we really need to be particularly proactive and particularly effective.

This is what our fellow citizens expect, to really be able to implement, in the very near future, procedures for the recognition of their qualifications, their skills, their professional qualifications, which are really faster, simpler, more efficient, less expensive.
This is a real challenge.

As shadow rapporteur for the EPP group on the subject of modernizing these procedures, I am actively working with the other members of the IMCO committee to truly respond to this major challenge of mobility.
More mobility, more Europe, that is what our fellow citizens are asking for. Thank you.
Mr. President, this year the Petitions Committee has acquired the right to be automatically associated for the hearing of European citizens'initiatives.
For me, this is the strong signal of the year two thousand and eleven for this Commission.
Citizens already had a commission to turn to in case of non-respect of their rights, but this is also the case now when they have proposals to improve European legislation.
I hope that the Petitions Committee can thus be increasingly considered the privileged interlocutor of citizens in the European Parliament.
This problem of consideration is also found in the results of the positions taken by the Petitions Committee.
Too often, we are approached by citizens who are faced with legal scams on which we would like to take a stand. But when the problems are European,
While the solutions should be European, we remain powerless, because subsidiarity still does not combine with European solutions due to a lack of national will.
I will take the difficult example of transnational divorces. The problems are both national and European when custody or visitation rights go beyond national borders, in this case that of Germany.
Despite the obvious difficulties for many parents in seeing their children born into binational unions, we in Parliament remain powerless to act.

My proposal that all European citizens should have the right to a national mediator, especially from Germany, which sends a lot of petitions, on the model of the rights defender in France, has not been followed by any effect.
However, in the case of transnational divorces, this remains a solution that reconciles European and national problems.
In many cases, European law seems powerless to meet the expectations of citizens.
The European Year of Citizens 2013 will have to deal with the complaints of citizens, listening to them, but we need ways to act to be
